column10:
(Almost Certain) Unpopular Opinion:
Sims 3 is better than Sims 4.

Yes, I have tried playing Sims 4, while it does have a lot more fine tuning when it comes to the creation of Sims and Infrastructure, it's the absolute atrocity that is the UI and Menu's that kill it for me. I also spent about $150 (AUD) on Sims 4 DLC's only for none of them to load/work despite spending hours troubleshooting. Gave in and refunded the whole lot.

Sims 3 at least works for me - I like that I have a lot of control over the creation of my neighbourhood and the more simple UI and menu options. The game is outdated unfortunately, which means using the Online services is either very difficult or impossible, but there is enough there for me to have had plenty of fun... and getting jealous that my Sim/s are having much better lives than I am xD
Just a fun and awesome way to pass time. Sims 3 has always been one of my personal favorites :)

I've been an avid sims four player since lockdown of 2020 and honestly playing the sims three is like a refreshing break from the slightly less in depth counterpart (TSF) i can genuinely get such realistic gameplay even just having base-game sims three. The reactions from sims, the dynamics between them make such greater sense. Yes - the graphics are considerably worse, it was made in 2007 after all, but its honestly made up for! Controversially i'm not a huge fan of open world but goodness do i not miss seeing the spinning plum bob loading screen everytime i want my sims to visit the beach or a restaurant. I do wish i was playing when it was in its prime so I could actually feel more confident purchasing packs for it since they're no longer getting updated. In conclusion, will i play the sims four more? Yes of course. But the sims three in terms of actual depth of game play gives it a real run for its money, arguably being a much better life simulator in general. Instead of buying another niche cash grab sims four gamepack actually buy TST. I can really tell there was so much more thought and effort into the little details. I don't get an overwhelming urge to download game-breaking mods so my sims can argue over a cheating scandal (like i do with the sims four) it already has that level of detail.

[h1]The Sims(TM) 3[/h1]

The Sims 3 was one of my favorite games since the release in 2009, I was stoked, I was always into The Sims as a kid, still am. Owning The Sims 1, The Sims 2, and now The Sims 3, I can say the improvement is very noticeable. I'm here to type this review since I had this game for quite some time, I've been addicted to the game recently so I figured to do this now while I'm inspired to do so.

[h1]What is The Sims?[/h1]
If you aren't familiar with The Sims, this is a kind of game with a Life Simulation, sure, playing with virtual dolls in a way, but somehow it's very addicting and quite relaxing. The Sims has a unique playstyle for each individual person. Some like to be architectural and build houses to pass the time. Some want to have their own challenges in creating a family and see how far the generations will go. Some people just want to drown their Sim for enjoyment just for the hell of it. These are just examples of what you can do.

[u]The Concept[/u]
Every Sims game has a "Needs" bar, to bathing, Eating, Entertainment, Social, these are examples. You would simply replenish these bars by cooking, watching tv, etc.

Your Sims are basically humans, they live under a house. You can build your own home and can really unleash your architectural talent, or just practice in general with your imagination. Otherwise, you can simply move your Sim into a pre-made house if you wish to. Living in these homes you can add furniture to whatever you desire to fit the lifestyle of your Sim.

Your Sims have a personality you can give them, do you want them to be romantic? You can do that. Do you want them to live miserable and happy? You can also do that. In The Sims 3, you are given more to give to your Sims compared to the other games, however, the concept stays the same.

You can also edit and dress your Sims to fit their personality as well. Do you want to give them a Tatoo? You can do that. Give them a Cowboy hat? Of course, you can also do that. [i]I'm sure you get the idea...right?[/i]

[h1]EA Game, must be DLC Hell.[/h1]

It is, unfortunately. The Sims is known for their expansions, however, most are indeed worth it. The Sims 3 is fair of $20 in my opinion, however not for most expansions by how old this game is. The Sims 3 does go on sale often to $5 including each of the DLC's often, so I would snag them when they reduce to that price.

In my opinion, I would recommend these Expansions to start out with:

- The Sims University = Enroll your Sims into a University for better jobs.
- The Sims Pets = You can add Cats, Dogs, Horses into your family.
- The Sims Seasons = Add Weather and Holidays in your gameplay.
- The Sims Late Night = Able to use Apartments and enjoy the Night Life
- The Sims Generations = More things to do, extending the Family Tree.
- The Sims Supernatural = Able to have Vampires, Werewolfs, Witches, etc.

The rest of the Expansions are optional, I can recommend them, these are just some I think would work best for most people, however, having all these Expansions will add more to your gameplay. Again, these do go on sale for $5, they are an absolute deal if you get them at that price.

[h1]The Sims 3 or The Sims 4?[/h1]

This section is very opinionated, The Sims 4 is an improvement for sure as your Sims can actually multitask on what they do, especially during socializing. The Sims 3 lacks that of course, it's older. Graphically I like The Sims 3 more than The Sims 4 because the 'Cartoon Graphics' 4 has personally displeased me. The Sims 4 Expansions weren't as fulfilling as The Sims 3 had for new content. The Sims 3 has an Open World where The Sims 4 does not, which does include performance issues that The Sims 3 has for weaker end systems, even stronger ones, I suffer with it sometimes.

Overall, each one has its advantages and disadvantages and just varies on taste. The Sims 4 is only available on Origin, however, at some point, we may see it on Steam since EA has been more open with Steam recently with newer titles.

Edit: I should say now The Sims 4 is able to be purchased on steam as this review is very outdated.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

I hope I provided enough, for people just looking into The Sims or Veterans, I can recommend this, full price at least for the game, though, again, the game does go on sale for $5, same as its expansions.

Modding support is still alive, in fact, I'm using some right now such as Worlds and Clothing for certain Sims. These can be easily accessed from a few websites.

So in conclusion, yes get this game.


[u]Some Mod Sites I used:[/u]

(Offical Sims 3 Site): https://store.thesims3.com/worldProductDetail.html?categoryId=12642
http://sims3.thesimscatalog.com/sims3/

the graphics are not the best but I love that the Sims act based off of the traits you give them. It is not a simple boost to skills but they will actually flirt on their own if flirty or if insane they will talk to themselves in the mirror. I also LOVE that it is more realistic. You can get cheated on or have a robber break in and steal your TV. I enjoy this version more then Sims 4 and wish that the newer version had some of the things that make the Sims 3 such a fun game to play in live mode.

Very immersive life simulator where you build a house, family, career and more. You can really build a house just how you want with nearly infinite design capability. The object of the game could be to satisfy the lifetime wish of your starting character but in a way the game has no goal except to enjoy yourself in a rich sandbox. It gets even more wacky and fun with the DLCs. Overall the game can be quite expensive with all the DLCs so I recommend wishlisting and waiting for a sale if you don't mind waiting.

The game has some serious bugs now and then that will make you want to cry. Look up how to install mods to solve the bugs before they happen. Also, the saving and loading can be excruciatingly slow if you don't have a good SSD. The marketing is aggressive and EA will try to sell you things in game but you can turn off some of it so it isn't too annoying.

Despite those issues, it's an extremely fun game with tons to explore. I recommend it.

iI bought a new gaming laptop Asus Rog Strix G16 (2023) with windows 11, 13th Gen Intel. 2.20 GHz. I have about 80% of the collection on discs so i instilled them and for some reason it would not work past the launch screen. I had someone tell me to buy them off Steam and i should have no problems with my newer computer. I was hesitant on it but i bought the whole bundle i mean why not i love the game and want to play it again!!! Well same issues as with the discs it wont go past the launch screen! I have checked my firewall settings, i have linked steam and my EA Account - I was told to launch it through EA. Wellllll My sims 4 linked to my EA but my sims 3 did NOT!!! SO i can play sims 4 on my new lap top but i have to pull the old dinosaur out to play sims 3. It was not a total lost since i was able to down load them off steam onto my old lap top and get the few expansions i was missing but the graphics suck!!!! So before you spend the money see if  your computer is compatible with the requirements to run the older software... I was hesitant on buying sims 4 but they are pretty close there are a few things i like way better on sims 3 but sims 4 is always an option if sims 3 wont work!
It was a nice run with this game. After many hours of playing this, Sims 3 will still be the best of the franchise imo. Cheers y'all

Sims 3 is a game that was [b]too ambitious[/b] for its time and PC specs in 2009..and it shows. It's one the best Sims games, but also has a lot of flaws, those mostly being its over-ambition. The game is laggy on modern PCs and requires mods for it to run smoothly [b](or even at all...)[/b], and for it to even support modern graphic cards. The Story Progression, though better than Sims 4's "story progression", is faulty as it leaves towns being ghost towns after 2-3 generations. Despite this, out of the two Sims games available to buy on Steam and Origin, Sims 3 has the best gameplay and CAS (solely for create-a-style with its colorwheel), has the best replayability and the better DLC, which are filled with tons of content. I wouldn't recommend this game at all however, if you don't have the storage and the ram to install mods to fix the framework of the Sims 3. I mean, with the Sims 4.. you're downloading mods not only to fix the framework of the game but the [i][b]literal gameplay foundations of it too[/b][/i]. Pick your poison. All in all, play the Sims 3... but buy it on sale.

i have a LOT of experience with the sims 2, 3 and 4 and i can tell you now that 3 is by far my favourite, from the immense open world system to sims with unique and memorable personalities - this game is great and you can tell a lot of love went into making it. the only problems i have with this game however, are the glitches and lags. some of the glitches where sims morph or get weird facial expressions are funny and if anything it makes the game more entertaining. but there are a ton of lags and bugs that make the game frustrating to play over long periods of time, most of these consist of sims freezing in place or clipping and just a lot of freezes and lags in general. so if you have the time i definitely recommend installing a smooth patch (if lags bother you a lot, do NOT get island paradise DLC). but other than the lags this game was a very big part of my childhood, but the reason i still play it today is because of all that you can do. in contrast with the sims 4, you can WALK AROUND OUTSIDE, skill building is more fun, you can go collect random rocks and seeds from parks, if you have seasons or pets you can go to non-worm hole events and take part in competitions or bets with your sim. this game has so much to offer and if you're into goofy life-sims where you can actually get attached to your sims i definitely recommend playing this game. (sims 2 is also great)

Do not pay full price for this game and, for the love of all that is holy, mod the heck out of this sucker.

That being said, the Sims 3 did some really cool things with the franchise. It was super ambitious for the time and is still impressive today. You have a crazy amount of control over so many tiny pixel lives. You can have two types of robot, a sparkly vampire, a rock star werewolf, a crazed mad scientist whose only job seems to be blowing things up, that old woman who told you get off her lawn but who is also a celebrity the likes of Tom Cruise in his prime, and several guinea pigs in the same house.  Not only that, but the entire house - the entire town - can be carefully arranged to look like an anime catgirl from above. And not only THAT, but you can make every single object, every single piece of clothing, every single thing your Sims ever touch have kickin' rad flames that make them go faster.

But it kind of fell flat on its face with optimization and actually implementing its great ideas. There's so much going on that by the time you've finished reading this sentence, before you've even purchased or installed the game, it will have overheated your computer and crashed to desktop. That's why you need the mods. You NEED the mods.

The typical Sims 3 experience

Every time I start up the game I have to adjust the game settings and resolution, which requires exiting the game and starting it up again. I also cannot recommend a game that has such expensive DLCs (even at 50% off) for a game that released well over a decade ago.

It's a pretty good game, it is important to note that Sims 4 is not an "upgrade" to Sims 3 nor is Sims 3 "better than" Sims 4. While Sims 3 is my personal favorite, both games have different aspects that make them better for separate purposes. The Sims 3 focuses mainly on a large, open world where you can have your sims explore their town freely, but it is more resource heavy than the Sims 4. Sims 4 is more optimized and has higher quality graphics, but there is NO open world aspect without mods. So in the end, I recommend BOTH games and leave it up to your personal preference. I would, however, say that if you have a potato, get Sims 4 since it is more optimized and runs smoothly.

I absolutely love this game. I've been playing it since I was 11 years old, so about a decade now. I don't even want to know the stupid amount of hours I had running the discs all summer long on my breaks. 

Look, I'm recommending based on the sheer amount of fun and replayability this game has offered me. It was a buggy mess in its prime and it runs even worse on modern computers. You'll have to tinker with it to get everything working properly, and you should still save often for when it inevitably crashes. 

There are some great guides on here which compile mods that greatly improve the performance, if you have the time for that. If you don't, play the Sims 4. I've finally started embracing the Sims 4 for what it is after refusing to touch it for the past 9 years (yes, it's been that long since a new Sims game.) But I will say, 3 just has this charm and life that 4... doesn't. 

EA has always been a greedy piece of shit company, and the DLC is absolutely NOT worth it unless you catch it on sale, even though vanilla gameplay kinda sucks. Even still, at least they weren't pumping out soulless, corporate Sims games unwilling to take risks or have any fun yet when this one came out.

I ended up liking and preferring TS3 so much that I paid to have all of the EPs and haven't gone back to TS4 but for an hour or so since. I can see why TS3 has a cult following with the open world and Create-a-Style abilities.

I'd recommend this game with a heaping pinch of salt.  I'm always finding new things but the timesink and amount of shit I have to google for obscure bugs or 'nraas mod did the thing' is insane.

With the age its at mods are essential to run it.  Poke around the Sims3 subreddit for suggestions but also look into the framerate capping as well, allegedly it can wreck your hardware over time by running a needless amount of frames per second.  The game is a decade old now as of its last expansion.

I like it a lot but the amount of times I have to play bug correction, mod micromanaging and googling a setting because nraas is doing shit that doesn't jive with my playstyle, learning how to do backups etc eats up a lot of time.  I use regul save cleaner, a more outdated attempt at such a software hosed my save at one point so be careful.  If not for "32bit game that didn't take 64bit into account with a 4GB hard cap limit" it'd be perfect but its not.  I have the time to google and play bugfix, a person with an actual job and responsibilities would not imo.

also yeah buy it on steam and not via EA's store as allegedly that bricked some peoples' hardware and requires being online to play the decade+ old offline game.

A little tricky to get running smoothly on modern hardware, but very very worth it once you do. The amount of fun you can get out of even the base game alone is pretty astounding. There's just so much for your Sims to do in each of the vast open neighbourhoods included. Throw a couple of DLC packs in there and the possibilities become near-endless. It really feels as though I've barely scratched the surface with my modest 113 hours. It's wonderful.

Like I said at the beginning though, getting things to run smoothly is a little bit of a hassle. Thankfully there are tons of helpful guides and fixes if you're willing to do a little digging. Rarely do you need to worry about anything else once those fixes are implemented too. The only other downside I can think of would be the prices of each DLC pack. While I believe a majority of them are worth the money, ten year old content should never remain full priced. Best wait for a sale on some of them. TS3 really is fantastic though and I'd recommend it to anyone who's in the mood for a really engaging, slightly chaotic life simulator.

Well... Good news!!!!
Not only am I giving this game a review of 1000 out of 10, but I am also going to tell you how to make this game work like a dream:

1. Look up the channel named SimMattically on youtube.

2. Find a video currently titled "How to Get Sims 3 and Make It Run | Recognizing GPU, Limiting FPS, Game Not Launching & Lag Fixes"

3. Follow this very simple and easy guide! It is so easy. If I can do it, then you can do it!

4. Not sure if he mentions this in the video seeing how I knew about this step before watching the video, but you need to figure out how many hertz your pc screen/monitor can handle. Mine is as 240, but I set my limit to 140. You need to set a limit as well. You might also have to do this in the ingame settings. (Again very easy) - lots of videos on youtube to help with this step, but for step 1 - 3 I suggest following Simmatically's guide (and he might mention this step as well). His guide was the one that worked for me, and the one that did not make me feel stressed out about what I needed to do.

Do me one favor. If you make this game work after following the guide, then give it a good review here on steam! Finally we can play a sims game that is actually fun and filled to the brim with content. And yes, The sims store still exists, so you can get even more content for the game than what is on steam! Big things like an amusement park and so on.
Should you do me this one favor, then please also give a shout out to Simmatically for telling us how to fix this game. This will help spread the word about how to play The sims 3 without any issues. Something I think a lot of people does not know about.

The Sims 3 isn't just a game; it's a boundless canvas for creativity, and with the vast array of downloadable content (DLC) at my fingertips, it has become a limitless universe of possibilities. From the moment I embarked on my virtual journey, I was captivated by the sheer depth and richness that the base game offered. The meticulous attention to detail, from the Sims' emotions to the intricate world-building, laid the foundation for an unparalleled simulation experience.

Now, having indulged in every expansion, stuff pack, and expansion content available, my Sims 3 universe has transcended the boundaries of virtual reality. The myriad of customization options, thanks to the DLC, transforms the game into a reflection of my wildest imaginations. Whether I'm building dream homes, shaping the destinies of my Sims, or exploring the diverse neighborhoods introduced by the expansions, each gameplay session is a unique and immersive adventure.

The expansion packs, in particular, are not mere additions but gateways to new realms of gameplay. Whether I'm delving into the supernatural mysteries of the 'Supernatural' expansion or building a bustling metropolis with 'Late Night,' each expansion seamlessly integrates into the core experience, enhancing the game's depth and ensuring that boredom is a concept that simply doesn't exist in my Sims 3 world.

The longevity of my enjoyment is a testament to the enduring appeal of The Sims 3, and the DLC has played a pivotal role in keeping the experience fresh and exciting. As I continue to uncover hidden gems and unlock new features, I find myself immersed in a virtual world that has become a cherished part of my gaming journey. In the realm of life simulation, The Sims 3, with its extensive DLC library, stands as an enduring masterpiece, offering a joyous and boundless escape into a world where imagination knows no bounds

I've played Sims since 2001 and this is EASILY the best Sims game in the entire franchise. From a Sims veteran to all you other vets and newcomers, this is the definitive Sims game. If you are a brand new Simmer or coming from 4, I recommend starting with just Sims 3 base game (there is PLENTY there to enjoy). If you are daring, you can buy Sims 3 with Seasons and Pets to flavor your game up. You need to make sure the game is right for you so obviously don't buy all DLC until you are sure you like it. 

I do warn you, though: if you have a very old machine then I don't recommend buying Sims 3. The open world and graphics while great make it lag like hell on older machines. Play at your own risk. There are guides out there that are dedicated to helping you make sure your Sims 3 runs as well as it can, but not all machines will like it. 

1. Your choices matter
How you create your Sim to the actions they take will affect the world around you (either very minimally or drastically) because there is an open world and your Sims personalities are very distinct. 

2. No micromanaging!
Sims 1 especially had this problem of micromanagement. No more queuing up three meals and five talk interactions; one meal satisfies your hunger (Mostly) and just one or two conversations makes your social go up. You might see this as a negative, but this actually gives you more time in the day to do things such as buying things or developing skills. Needs decay also a bit more slowly than they did in 1 and 2 so you aren't constantly keeping your needs green.

3. Careers are far better
You can also do things with your Sims while they are off at work or at school! You can adjust how they work or what they do (granted they are rabbit holes but it's better than nothing). You can meet your students/coworkers or develop skills WHILE working. It's also no longer "You must have this required thing for a promotion" as it's more like "you must be in this range for a promotion" so you can still progress. Things such as challenges and relationships also affect job progression. Getting level 5 in a certain skill will impress your boss, raise your pay, etc. 

4. Building is fantastic
You can place almost every object in whatever x-plane orientation you want if you hold down ALT (which means you can turn off the grids). You no longer have to tear down rooms and things to fix a house problem; you can just expand the room or use blueprint mode! There is also create-a-style, which basically lets you put whatever you want on anything. Wanna put leopard print on your fridge? Do it. Want to make your car out of bricks? Do it. You can adjust individual colors and even set your own shades with them! 

5. Open world
Sims 1 and 2 were closed world, which sadly made you a prisoner of your own home. Granted, Sims 1 is the first so I get it. Sims 2 could have easily done it. Sims 3 does and it does it so well... despite the optimization errors. Mostly no loading screens and I can see the world be alive! 

6. So much on offer
I remember back when I first bought Sims 3 base and played that for probably 100 hours minimum before I even bought an expansion (it wasn't through Steam). It can keep you hooked for a VERY long time. Even the day this review was edited, I had a six-hour session in 3 and had a blast throughout it. 

7. Progression takes time
In sims 3, it takes a VERY long time to pick yourself up off the ground from nothing. You need to hone all your skills, make connections, and save those pennies before you can start moving up. Sims 1 and 2 had this progression, but Sims 1 was also a constant clickfest due to the motives decaying so quickly and Sims 2 felt a bit too fast for me. Sims 3 hits it JUST right and oh so perfectly. 

8. It's so damn fun
The most important thing about a game is the fun factor: this game absolutely nails it. I have a blast playing all the time. 

Despite the obvious problem of the buggy open world, this game is an absolute gem. Like I said, I have played Sims 1 probably the most out of all these games with Sims 3 seriously catching up. Sims 3 is THE best Sims game.

Easily the best iteration of the series due to the breadth of activities and content at your disposal, and having an active neighborhood where other sims age and grow at the same pace as your household.

The one caveat is that you need to install a few third party mods to get it to run on modern hardware, but setting everything up is not particularly time consuming:

https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/The_Sims_3#Essential_improvements

The cost of the full game seems ridiculous given the last expansion came out 10 years ago as of this writing, but I'd argue it's still a much better deal than what The Sims 4 has to offer. At any rate, it's definitely worth grabbing when it's on sale.

Why this review is positive:

This has been my favorite game since I was 13. Sims 3 is the only open world game in the series, and the DLC gives you way more content for your money than Sims 4 does. (Still overpriced though lol) I have 2000+ hours and I'm not bored yet.

The two main issues with this game that you might want to consider before buying it:

1. It's buggy / unoptimized if you don't have the patience to install mods. The worst example of this is the lack of a framerate cap or vsync option, which causes it to run at 1000+ fps on some newer graphics cards if you don't get LazyDuchess's smooth patch mod. NRaas mods also help a lot with the bugs.

2. The character customization without mods is much less expansive than in The Sims 4.

Without mods this is unplayable on new machines. However it remains the best Sims game to date with plenty to do. Looking back I do not miss any of the features introduced in 4 when I come back to 3. Definitely worth a play if you can get it working.

In my humble opinion, it is the best Sims game on the market. The amount of content (when DLC are considered) is truly astonishing and can leave people who have spent years playing in awe of how many things there are to discover. There are many cases where people posted online about a certain feature, object, mechanic of the game that they've just discovered in spite of playing for so long. 
But even without the DLC, this game is fairly content-filled as this is the only game with an open-world like gameplay which hits the jackpot. This adds so much to the atmosphere of a way a player perceives the town their characters live in. You get to see how it's changing, evolving, how families come and go, what legacy they leave behind (especially when you mod the game) and only the Sims 3 has ever done it.
Okay, indeed this implementation is not without its limits and problems. If you purchase many dlcs and launch the game, it is not optimized correctly and you pretty much need optimizing mods (which are thankfully easy to install and apply to the game) even if you own a very good PC this game WILL lag and cause you problems if you do not install mods.
If you can withstand this, you are in for a few thousand hours worth of content, the biggest potential in comparison to all Sims games (The sims 4 included) hands down. The graphics are okay, maybe not outstanding but good enough not to complain and they can be successfully enhanced by mods, too. Soundtrack is very sims like (who would have thought) but I'd argue it is the most fitting balance of a magical and optimistic vibe without sounding almost annoying like it sounds in the Sims 4.
And, what's imperative to mention, these were the times when EA still (somewhat) cared about their customers or at least showed them proper respect so the DLCs truly bring a lot of content that makes the game as the whole. It's not just a bunch of small add-ons posing to appear as something bigger than they really are.
If you are looking for a life simulator and you are thinking about the Sims 3- do not think twice, buying it (and managing its limitations and errors) will pay off.

This isn't going to be the most detailed review, and I can really only compare this to the Sims 4, as I never played the other sims - except for the Sims 2 and Sims Medieval very briefly.

Firstly, yes, the graphics aren't exactly great (but they're still bearable) but I still believe the compromise is worth it. I like the fact that whenever you travel somewhere, it doesn't put you into a loading screen and instead you get to see your sim travel there - whether it be via a jog, run, taxi or a car that you have purchased - this of course is personal preference but I really don't see why it's a thing in the Sims 4. Another thing is the Pets DLC. In the Sims 4, for some bizarre reason, you have no control over the pets. However, in the Sims 3, you get to control the pets and interact with them as you would with any other sim in the game.

In conclusion, from the very few details I've listed: the Sims 3 is most definitely better than the Sims 4.

Now THIS is gaming.

Let's go back to 2009, the beautiful late 00s. Gaming was PEAK at this point and fans had no reason to expect something revolutionary. The Sims 2 was considered nearly flawless, making the obvious followup one of the most hyped releases of the decade. What new adventures awaited in the next installment?

Well I didn't get to find out cuz as we all know Walmart laptops from 2007 were terrible. Wit no $$$ and hopes of getting any game to run, I gave it up and stuck to owning noobs in Call of Duty.

Fast forward to 2021, and I decided that since gaming went to shit I'd look back at some titles I missed out on when I was coming up. Obviously, the Sims 3 was a biggie and h.o.l.y.s.h.i.t.

This game is perfect. Addicting game play, an open world, TONS of customization, great music (the fact that Need You Know is in this game is so 2009), and just a sense of care and polish you don't get from many games. I refuse to note the crashing errors because 1.) They're surprisingly not as bad as you'd think from a game this old and 2.) This wasn't really designed for Windows 10, despite the fact that it runs well regardless. If you have performance issues, there are a lot of simple things you can do to improve the performance or you can just download some mods.

What other game let's you play as a household of R. Kelly and die from sleep deprivation while stalking Lil' Bling outside his gated mansion? Or let's you play as an obese, vampire OJ Simpson and cause havoc on the town? None that I know of.

Buy this game. Buy the DLC. Download mods. Escape reality. You have no choice, I am literally forcing you to play this masterpiece.

A warning for anyone intending to play this game for an extended period of time: it has memory leak issues which could render the game almost unplayable; however, they are easily patched by the fan community.

The Sims 3 is more than just a game—it's a captivating and immersive life simulation experience that never ceases to amaze. From the moment you dive into its virtual world, you're greeted with endless possibilities and a sense of freedom that's unparalleled. The level of detail in creating your Sims is astonishing, allowing you to sculpt their personalities, appearances, and aspirations to your heart's content.

But what truly sets The Sims 3 apart is its open-world environment. Gone are the loading screens between locations, replaced by a seamless and vibrant world that your Sims can explore at will. This change brings a new layer of depth to gameplay, as you watch your Sims traverse the neighborhood, forming relationships, pursuing careers, and engaging in a myriad of activities with a natural flow.

The customization options extend beyond just the Sims themselves, as you're given an incredible range of tools to design homes that reflect your imagination. The architecture and interior design possibilities are limitless, ensuring that every abode you create is a unique masterpiece.

The attention to detail is astounding, from the day-to-day routines of your Sims to the dynamic weather that affects their lives. This level of realism adds a sense of authenticity that draws you in and keeps you invested in the virtual lives you're shaping.

Whether you're a casual player or a dedicated simulation enthusiast, The Sims 3 offers something truly special. It's a game that encourages creativity, fosters relationships, and provides an escape into a world where your imagination can run wild. Even years after its release, The Sims 3 remains a shining example of how a game can combine innovation, customization, and sheer entertainment to create an unforgettable experience.

Just in case someone is having Issues, here is a Guide that i make.

The Sims 3 - This is the solution to launch the game !!!

I have the solution, it is not necessary to patch or any type of mods, so if possible post this comment, because I have been looking for a solution for about 6 months that in the end is simple.

Step 1: Install the game, either via Steam or elsewhere.

Step 2: Open The Sims 3 (Desktop Icon After Installation)

Step 3: When the launcher is open we don't click play, instead we open the "task manager", right click on the sims 3 Launcher and click on "go to details".

Step 4: In the details, look for "TheSims3LauncherW.exe", right-click on it, and choose "set affinity". The numbers with the CPU will appear, the only one to be marked is the one that says "CPU 1", the others are to be left unmarked. then click "OK". (Note that this is the key step to make it work, but it's very, very simple.)

Step 6: Click Play on The sims 3 Launcher, everything is normal. when the game opens, the black screen with the EA symbol appears, we do not turn off the game, but go to the desktop and open the task manager again.

Step 7: in the task manager repeat the same steps, on the right side of the manager click on "processes", then right-click on "The Sims 3" and choose "Go to details".

Step 8: In the details search for "TS3W.exe" right-click and choose "set affinity". Mark all CPUs as enabled, the 5 CPUs must be marked. Then click "OK", close the Task manager and you are ready to play with the power of your computer.

Very simple steps, in 1 to 2 minutes the problem is solved.

Every time you play you have to do this, but it's very quick to do, it's not worth installing any kind of patch or mod, it's a simple solution.

Ps: The Guide works with mods or without mods, is the same solution. A big hug for you all

If you have a creative mind, lots of time on your hands, are fine with occasional crashes or bugs, and love simulation games, this game is definitely for you.

UPDATE 8/18/23 -
I have decided to play this game more in order to get used to the controls, and I've also purchased more DLC for it. I can say without a doubt, that I really do love this game and it is such a nice break away from Sims 4. They continue to put out more expansion packs, more kits, etc but will not fix broken things with the game - which there is A LOT that needs to be fixed. I know by buying Sims 3 content I'm still putting money in their pocket, which sucks.. but at least it's a better game. I wish they would bring Sims 2 back but I don't see that ever happening, I would give anything to own that entire collection again. But I still highly recommend Sims 3, and some of the DLC.

This is the best of the Sims games because of Create a Style - for any clothing/furniture/thing, you can click the palette button, which lets you change the RGB values of the different parts of the items, select textures to apply, basically you can fully customise the appearance of everything in the game.

The big downside to this game is the very long loading times. Especially if you own all the DLCs.

Neighborhoods work differently in Sims 3. Your whole neighborhood is active at once, and you can send your Sim off to walk around the whole place. A saved game covers every household of this neighborhood. The downside compared with Sims 4 is you can't visit other neighborhoods (but you can move a household to a new neighborhood).

Sims 4 has a buy mode search function, which Sims 3 really suffers for not having.

Sims 4 has more customisation of the actual Sims than this game.

Build mode is pretty good. There are a lot of fun workarounds you can find on youtube (the barn roof trick is one of the better ones to know). I can't decide whether Sims 3 or 4 has a better build mode, they're both good in different ways.

Sim Autonomy - I like the Sim and pet behaviours of this game more than Sims 4. In Sims 4, guests visit your house and barge into your Sim's bedroom to play games on their PC for the whole party. Sims 3's autonomy is a lot better than Sims 4's.

If you like Pets, then Sims 3 lets you control your pets directly. In Sims 4, you had to tell your Sim to tell the pet to do something. Sims 4 - if you don't tell your sim to tell their pet dog to go to bed at night, the dog will stand there looking at its bed until it passes out from fatigue.

The Steam Store has a bundle with all the DLCs, which for some reason does not appear on the main Sims 3 page.
https://store.steampowered.com/bundle/1247/The_Sims_3_Collection/
The downside is having all the DLCs really bloats the buy mode. You cannot easily turn off any DLCs. If you untick them in Steam properties, the game will not launch.

Expansion DLCs:
1 World Adventures - vacation locations of France, China and Egypt. 

2 Ambitions - Some great professions with fun minigames are added, such as Private Investigator, Architect, Ghost Hunter. Neigbhorhood - Twinbrook added, French Bayou theme.

3 Late Night - Vampires, Rock bands and Clubs. A Chicago/Seattle like neighborhood with high rise apartments.

4 Generations - Adds a whole lot more content for children. Buy this if you like raising families. Has no neighborhood, but has a lot of very nice prebuilt homes.

5 Pets - cats, dogs and horses! Neighborhood - Appaloosa Plains, a ranch town

6 Showtime - adds singing, magician, acrobat careers. Neighborhood is Starlight Shores, a Hollywood themed town. Starlight Shores has some nice retro buy-mode items and mid-century modernist architecture.

7 Supernatural - Adds fairies, witches, werewolves and zombies. Town - Moonlight Falls, Pacific Northwest / Twilight inspired.

8 Seasons - adds seasons. Also aliens.

9 University - adds a university campus neighborhood. Sims can't live in the neighborhood, it's more like a vacation location, they live there temporarily while they study. Upgrades smart phones and adds social groups (jocks, rebels and nerds).

10 Island Paradise - Isla Paradiso neighborhood, adds mermaids and lots of water-related activities.

11 Into the Future - Lets sims travel to the future neighborhood of Oasis Landing. Travelling back to the past will allow you to make changes that affect the future.

Most recommended expansions, depending on gameplay style: Ambitions, Late Night, Pets, Generations, Seasons, Supernatural.

The Stuff packs are all what they say on the tin. The Katy Perry Sweet Treats pack seems to no longer be available (basically tonnes of furniture that looked like cupcakes)

Mods: You need mods to solve a bunch of problems https://www.nraas.net/community/Mods-List
Error Trap, Master Controller, Overwatch and Story Progression are the most recommended.

See this guide for a lot of ways to improve the game https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1131162350

I like this product because I grew up playing it as a kid and fell in love with the downloadable content I chose: the Supernatural pack. Now I'm able to revisit this gem and play it to my extent. One downside is minor one, but my first Sim got bitten by a zombie, which goes to show that you should be careful under a full moon. Other than that, I was able to buy the game myself and start over with one human and two renevant zombies that are supposed to portray my own original characters as Sims. Yes, they're original characters I made: I'm a cartoonist in real-life as a hobby, and I tend to create my own characters on paper. Zombiepeople was not my initial work (that title goes to my original original characters in Rob & Nul) but I was able to use this game's Sim customization feature to retool them into my own Sim characters. People seem to do whatever with their Sims instead while I created my own as good-hearted, friendly, and non-judgemental in nature. That is one of my aspects of my Sims and I am proud of them, but I won't let that get to my head as I balance gaming with the rest of my own life. I recommend this game based on that experience of mine.

If you are having issues with launching the game. Follow this:
1. open task manager 
2. open sims launcher
3. Before pressing play on sims launcher - locate Sims3LauncherW in task manager
4. Right click and set affinity to CPU 1 only
5. Press Play 
6. once sims 3 is successful - minimise and set affinity to all processes and continue playing 

Hope this helps

What I dislike about this game: It quickly overheats your laptop (depending on the make of the laptop) and I have found limited clothing choices. I do not like the building restrictions, not being able to build building taller then five floors tall and the limit of eight sims per household.

Heads up if you have a newer computer:

The collection bundle is tempting (I know because it tempted me (steam summer sale)) but you will NEED to follow a guide to make it ***playable***. I knew this going into it, but I feel bad for anyone who spends 100+ bucks just to have the game not work. You can get it to work, but you need to do a good bit of modding.

I am only a novice at modding, but there are some very helpful guides from the community on steam. I spent about 3 hours following guides to help with the game's performance and I was able to make it functional - I believe that if I can do it you can do it. It will crash/freeze every now and then, but I could probably do more research and mod it more to fix it further. For now I am just saving the game... often.

Still a much better game than Sims 4. I'm having a lot of fun, even dealing with the glitches, and that's saying something.

I bought The Sims 3 + Pets back in 2013 in a bundle that was also on sale for $17.

I bought the Seasons expansion in 2018 while it was on sale for $5.

And finally I missed a mega bundle deal some time after that, that had all the missing DLC's I didn't have for like $60 or something. I vowed that if I ever found a big deal like that again on Steam that I would buy it no matter what it cost me.

Because buying all the DLC for $450 is just stupid. (EA being EA)

The next bundle came in 2019. I got everything in a Mega Bundle deal, one being a Bundle of the Stuff Packs I was missing, and the other being a Bundle of the Expansion Packs I was missing. The total was $79.

(Also, this isn't me telling you to do it, but: They don't sell Katy Perry's DLC anymore. And for me, I wasn't accepting that. Let's just say... with a little Googling, you can get yourself a download of Katy Perry's Sweet Treats and install it into the files with the rest of the Packs, and the launcher lights up Katy Perry's Pack icon just like normal, and then you have the "Complete Collection")

Now, in today's age, I doubt you'll get that lucky anymore, with how hard they're pushing TS4. But honestly, if you ever find a deal like I did, snatch it up. The Sims 3 is far better than The Sims 4, even if it's a little choppy. Just get MasterController, and NRaas.

Those Mods handle cleaning up stuff around the world, and turning off stuff the NPCs leave on. And just generally makes it run a little better.

Then, personally, you should check out Fresh Prince's car mods for TS3. Because that open world is what makes TS3 better than TS4.

I tried TS4, and it just doesn't feel the same as TS3, even if it looks better I wouldn't take TS4 over TS3 any day.

I hate this game.

If you're only here for the meme of someone with almost 2000 hours in a game not recommending it, thank you for your participation, please find the nearest exit because I'm about to go on a long written rant about why I hate this game.

-------------

This is a full priced beta. Anyone who has played more than 10 hours of the game will realize VERY quickly that the Sims 3 is an unfinished game that's only made technically worse by its expansions. What's worse than this is the fact that they're still charging you full price for this piece of garbage. Models bug constantly. You need to have multiple save files in case of crashes or game breaking glitches. Certain expansions will just break your game entirely, I'M LOOKING AT YOU ISLAND EXPANSION. 

There is no technical support for this game, and GOD HELP YOU if you're trying to connect to the servers in modern day. There are online options that simply do not work at all, any longer. This might be where you remind me that this game is 14 years old. This is where I will remind you that they're still charging FULL PRICE for the game and its expansions. 

And yet somehow this is the best life simulator that's on the market right now.

Some people will prefer Sims 1, 2, or 4 to Sims 3 and I totally understand why. These have very different approaches than Sims 3. However, Sims 3 gives you a level of customization, narrative control, and user tools that none of the other games have. Even without mods, you can basically do whatever you want. 

If you can get it working.

If it doesn't bug out or crash on you.

If you pay enough money.

I blame two things for the Sims 3 being a bad game.

1. It's ahead of its time. I don't even think the tech is there now to completely fulfill every problem that exists in the game. There's just so MUCH of it. Graphic quality and animation fluidity aside, just the coding alone must have been hell on the developers for the sole reason of keeping track of everything. Even with my 1700+ hours I was still discovering new things that were possible in the game right up until my last uninstall. Even if it was technically possible to accomplish everything and make it even just slightly bug free, I don't think the average PC could run it. 

2. EA got its grubby little hands on it. I don't need to type out anything else to explain this to you, and that should tell you how bad this problem is. 

I'm going to say more things now, and then I'm going to conclude this review. These are criticisms regarding the PUBLISHER, which is relevant to this review. 

EA gets away with this because the majority of the Sims' player base is under 18. The majority of the people who play the Sims are not savvy with or educated on the markets, and have a very narrow concept of finances. That's not an insult to the players, this is a life experience thing. In 5 years you'll be looking back going 'ah man, I really should have done this and paid more attention to that', that's normal, we ALL have that happen ESPECIALLY with digital items.

My point is that a lot of people who buy into the Sims, people of ALL ages despite the scales being tipped in the favor of those older, don't actually realize what they're buying or what it's worth. EA shouldn't give things away for free, they're a business. They have employees and they provide a service, they need to make money. Charging full price for almost a 15 year old game, as well as every expansion that's come out for it, that's seeing no updates and no tech support isn't just scummy, it's dangerous. Server maintenance for online services is important, the older things are and the more stagnant they sit, the more risk there is to your information and account. I bet a lot of people have debit or credit card information linked to their online service accounts. Emails, birthdays, passwords, all of these things are vulnerable. 

You're screwed if you want to get into the online presence. You're screwed if you've been there in the past. You're screwed if you buy the wrong expansion. You're limited in the game if you only buy the base game. It will literally cost you hundreds of dollars to buy this decade and a half old game in order to see it in its full state, and you might not even be able to run it at all.

**BUYER BEWARE**   

This game runs like crap on modern hardware. It gets super choppy, takes FOREVER to load on many screen transitions, and crashes frequently, and characters just stop functioning at times.  Steam's customer service with my issue has been atrocious.  Steam just keeps giving me the wild goose chase linking me to tips to make it work (which i tried, and it didn't work) instead of just making the customer happy and giving a refund.  It's not like they lost the product, it's just a copy of software! I DID NOT PLAY THE GAME FOR 6 HOURS!!   It didn't shut down properly after the first FAILED ATTEMPT TO PLAY IT and it ran up the "clock".  i spent those 6 hours trying to implement the "fixes" (that didn't work) and doing research on the problem.  Apparently it happens to a LOT of people on this game.  if Steam had just given the refund of $110 for the game and DLC bundle i paid for, i would have used it on Sims 4 DLC's...  

No worries though.  I WONT be spending any more money on this platform unless i get my much deserved refund.  I'll buy my games elsewhere from now on.  This has been VERY disappointing treatment of a LONG term customer of 15+ years.  I'm not trying to pull some scam here, but i paid good money for a product i CANNOT EVEN USE! Imagine a place, where you can create your dream town. All the shops you want, housing along a coast, neighborhoods full of characters. In the center of it all lies a big, beautiful park where seasonal activities can (or not) occur. A place where you can create the family of your dreams. It's your place. Your dream...

Now image a place where your sim terrorizes the entire neighborhood because they have the 'Evil' trait. You have a house and a sim lock inside, without a door, making you money because you are exploiting your fellow 'workers' to write books for you. Image creating your 'dream' family, which is not-at-all an abomination, consisting of: Blue man, a raccoon-cat hybrid, and a lady whose neck is 2 ft long. It's the 'perfect' family.

In the Sims 3, YOU can do anything you dream of (If you have the DLCs for it :| )! 

Do you want a one-bedroom house with 8 sims living inside? Go right ahead!
Do you want to mooch off other sims and steals their wives? You can do that!
Do you want to become a millionaire quickly by exploiting a glitch because EA forgot to patch it? No one is stopping you!

TL:DR: Just buy the game

I used to love The Sims 3. I first got The Sims 3 when DVD discs where still relevant, and my first expansion pack was Late Night and Supernatural. I have very fond memories of my sim (I think it was Lola) wooing Matthew Hamming (that rich 4/5 star celeb dude) and cheating on her bf, and in Supernatural's town I made a vampire sim bite most of the people in the town to make them into vampires. Vampire dominance for the win! 

I also remember getting Island Paradise (which is very buggy on my pc now :( ) and having amazing houseboats and trying to make a good hotel, whilst also trying to make my male sim into a mermaid, and exploring the map as it was very cool to see all the cool little details on the map.

I then got all the other expansion packs, but other than World Adventures, Into the Future (I have my qualms with it, though) and Pets, they were either:

- Buggy (Island Paradise, and the Zombies from Supernaturals)

- Laggy (Island Paradise was SO laggy, i couldn't even play for longer than 20 minutes)

- Lacklustre (Diesel Stuff and some of the other packs, for the money they charged back at least 7 years ago is astonishing... even now. There wasn't very many items to make your homes unique, especially if you've played the game for so long that every item just looks... meh. Or you have to buy "SimPoints" from the ol' Sims website to access other item packs or other maps.)

- Prone to crashes, especially on maps like Isla Paradiso (from Island paradise expansion pack) and even Moonlight Falls (Supernatural)

It's a real shame because The Sims 3 was a staple in my gaming collection, as it was my childhood game. But coming back to this and seeing the state it is in, is depressing. EA has really milked it dry, and left it to rot.

If you have gotten down here and read through all that, thanks for reading. If you still do want to buy it, there are mods you can download to fix some of the issues in The Sims 3 and improve performance and adds in commands if your sim(s) are bugging out, though do be careful of Custom Content sites that aren't official or if they aren't from NexusMods (not sure if Steam Workshop actually works with the Sims? A bit strange, they're missing out there). Hope this helps!

I've gotten too much joy from this game growing up. Love the open world, love the style, love the improvements from 1 and 2, love how engrossing it is getting caught up in your sim's life. It is questionable to many whether Sims 3 or 4 is better. I definitely prefer the fact that I don't need Origin to play 3.
Loading time tends to be the main drawback to 3, but this is mainly when booting the game up. I think the Sims 3 was a great medium in style between 1 and 4. Not too flowery and silly like 4 while still having alot more of that style that was missing from 1.
I've played all 4 games for hundreds of hours and I don't personally think there's any clear winner between 3 and 4. But generally I find myself falling back to 3. So if you want, try both for yourself. But I would recommend 3 as my personal favourite.

My second favourite Sims game (my first being Sims 2) The open world of this game was very ambitious of them to do, and I think it paid off for the most part. No longer do you need to look at loading screens to load into new lots; simply go to the map and click the lot you want to go to, and then there you go. The only downside to the open world is the performance issues it brings, especially on modern systems.

The games database for GPUs stopped being updated around 2014, if I remember correctly, and because of this, it won't recognise newer GPUs. There are guides on Steam and online that show you how to fix this and many other problems with this game, but the amount of fixes you have to do for an enjoyable experience is almost absurd. These problems are all easily fixable; it's just that it shouldn't really be required of the user to fix them. Update your game, EA!

Besides these issues, this game is an absolute blast to play, and the majority of the DLCs are very enjoyable, especially Seasons. Tonnes of love have been put into this game, and the amount of stuff you can do is pretty much endless. It is absolutely worth picking this game up, but wait for a sale.

EA is charging way too much for a decade-old game; they even increased the price of the DLCs! As of writing this review, the game and all of its DLCs are currently on sale, and there is a complete collection of all the DLC available on Steam that is being hidden by EA. Thankfully, there are some very nice people in the review section that have left links to the collection, so if you're going to buy the DLC, do it through that bundle. You will be saving yourself a tonne of money.

Far better for gameplay and immersion than Sims 4,  more surprises, excitement, an open world (just walk out of your apartment building in Bridgeport and go roam around the city on foot, or better yet, your motorcycle or car), more depth, more personality, more consequences, more realism. The ability for Sims to do things that are interactive with actual animations (such as slow dancing as a couple holding onto one another, sparring together in martial arts, jamming with other musicians, sets it apart from Sims 4 in which most "together" interactions are done more by themselves, next to someone else doing it by themselves, in parallel without any apparent interaction.  The worlds are bursting with lots, zany townies, playable buildings (though grocery shopping, grade school, and many others are rabbit holes). You don't have the flexibility of going between worlds/towns the way you could in Sims 4, though. But you also don't have loading screens when you leave your house to go visit your neighbor, or even walk or drive down to the beach or riverside, and you can travel. 

Another reason to get Sims 3 on Steam, is that it uses the next-to-latest version instead of the latest, which is good because the latest version eliminated Create-A-World for those who want to form worlds of their own design, choose venues and housing, and share those worlds with each other.

Sims 3 does need NRAAS mods and for the user to learn the do's and don'ts to keep it in good running order due to issues with modern systems and some issues that were baked in from the start (but all Sims games have issues that were baked in from the start and require management). but it seems a small price to play for better gameplay and immersion.

I moved into a cheap one bedroom house with a household of four people.

Over the years, I rarely spoke to any of them. Didn't have any friends, except the car I bought. My sister became the CEO of a multinational corporation, one roommate landed on mars, and the other became the president of the United States of America.

However, I was stuck upstairs, in a (now furnished) attic remodeled to be a study because the house was so small, behind a computer churning out smut novels to my 3 adoring fans and gaining less than $500 a week in royalties- I worked a desk job at a low-budget newspaper company to try to even keep up with the success around me. 

Eventually, the Astronaut got married, moved out, had a kid, started a life. I heard he died peacefully in his sleep. His passing got me thinking about myself; is there anything more than this minutia? Anything more than the grind of living day to day in this infernal repetitive hell?

I took a trip to the graveyard, visiting the headstone of my passed acquaintance, to think about how I could possibly save my future. Sat down on a bench near a pond and observed the carefree and unaware fish meander about and passively feed on algae and the like. Didn't really keep track of time, It's pretty dark out now. In the corner of my eye a dim, pale-blue glow engulfed half of the bench. Slowly and carefully, a Translucent, Floating, Dripping(???), 30-something woman sat down next to me. I wasn't sure if i accidentally ate some bad food or maybe i was up too late, but before me she sat, as real as i could perceive.
She introduced herself. I put the immediate shock behind me and hesitantly introduced myself.
We talked for hours, eventually we started flirting.
I left that graveyard that night with a renewed sense of self esteem and a kiss from a hot ghost milf.
I now KNEW what I had to do.

I quit my job.
I petitioned the graveyard to give me her headstone.
I committed a heinous sin against the gods and paid mystical people money I don't have to allow her to remain in the realm of the living during all hours of the day.

With both of our lives together planned and the road forward paved, our love blossomed. With all the additional free time away from work I fixed my social life, purchased properties, continued my writing, and furthered hobbies I haven't touched in years. She saved my life from ruin and I couldn't thank her enough. I proposed to her on a quiet beach at sunset.

Before I knew it, I was pregnant. Had three little ghost babies with her. Even though I hated children, seeing my own fruit grow before my eyes was really moving.

The president died. I didn't attend his funeral, neither did my sister. 
The reality is that we were all aging. I could start to count my grey hairs and my older sister already had a head of silver. 
I thought about my wife. Her age suspended in time, just like she was the day she drowned.

She was at work. I was sitting on the beach, next to the ruined pier, watching the starts orbit above me, immutable and piercing as they would ever be. I look to the heavens, up towards the dark and hallowed sky. That night, one lone star in the sky was unfamiliar, larger and brighter than the rest. On closer inspection, it appears to be getting brighter by the sec-

I awoke on a small wooden boat opposite to a hooded figure with dark robes, rowing aimlessly across a black sea with no horizon. I didn't speak. After a few moments of silence, he looked up, noticed me, and calmly removed his oars from the water. Setting the oars besides him, he told me that it was painless, and that nobody was around to witness my body become viscera. I asked him what he meant. He took his hood off, his flesh was missing entirely from his body. He told me that he was the harbinger of souls, and that I had died. I stood up and begged him to return me to my family. He shook his head and told me there was nothing he could do. I began to sob. He snapped his fingers and everything went black. 

I was in bed. My wife was besides me. It was dark outside. Bad dream. I was kinda thirsty, and a little cold. Some tea would warm me up. I went to remove my blankets, but from beneath them came a flaming hand glowing with a fierce orange hue. I screamed. Jeannie stood up and seeing my distress, immediately went to comfort me. She tells me that I had died. She took my tombstone to the mystics like I did hers and made me like her, an immortal spirit unbeholden to societal expectation. I began to cry, I'm not sure if they were tears of joy or sorrow.

I do not know what gods put me on this earth and I do not know what sick form of humour they have. But I am thankful for the boons they have gifted me. This new life, this new ME, is invigorating. I knew that from this day forward I would seize every single day and enjoy every bestowed aspect of my new self. I am now, finally, me.

The Sims 3 is a great 'open world'(in the sense that it loads in at once, no in-between screens to go to another zone) game filled with lively characters and things to do. It balances Mood icons, character expression/NCPs/customization, Wishes, the building, random encounters better than any Sims game in my own opinion. Super fun! 

Literally does not work on modern PC's. I say modern as in Windows 11 or 12th gen Intel Core processors. It is, I think, unfair to recommend a game that literally does not run without knowledge of modding on a modern device. Even when the Sims 3 DID run it ran badly. The memory leak is so bad and chews your RAM up so much I personally modded anyways just for some patches. 

Pricing and DLC:
One DLC is no longer available(lost license with Katy Perry). The SIms 3 is super old, well over a decade actually as of writing, and yet it and all its DLC are ~$20 USD. 19 DLC at $19.99 USD plus base game, which although plenty fun is bare bones considering the amount of content locked behind said DLC. To own all of The Sims 3 game+DLC is ~$400 USD(no tax). But that's unfair! Sales and bundles exist and I should take advantage! For a decade+ old game that rarely goes on sale, bundled with DLC I might not even want, anyways! With all the bugs and no fixes from the DLC's own issues they had a decade or longer ago! Nothing new for The Sims fan, doesn't mean it's right.

Generic pro-tips for the interested:

-Dumpster dive regularly for random fun items and easy cash selling free stuff

-Play randomly to get the most out of the game over repeating 'your' ideal family. It's more interesting and fun to explore

-Mod the game to save your PC some trouble

TECHNICALLY I would endorse this game, but only if you're willing to put in a lot of legwork to make it function. It's insanely addictive, but so, so broken.

TL;DR: Check out Anime_Boom's wonderful "The Sims 3 Performance & Bug Fix Guide". If you like management games and life sims, and if that seems like a reasonable amount of work to put in just to enjoy a game beyond an extremely cursory level (Wherein you'll have to accept the presence of bugs that, at times, can ruin entire save files), then you'll have a total blast with this game! If not, I'd look elsewhere. The Sims 2 is also pretty busted, but it can still work as an alternative.
---

A good summation of that is the fact that my playtime for TS3 is actually *much* higher than the 93 hours Steam has logged, but it can't track my playtime anymore because I've had to start bypassing the launcher when I load it up. If I don't, the game gets stuck running in my system tray, and it won't close out normally when I quit.

If you're playing with hardware that's even remotely modern, you'll need to manually reach into the game's guts to force it to recognize your graphics card, or else it'll act like you don't have one at all. You'll also need to manually allow it to utilize more system RAM, because on default it caps at 2 gigs. So basically, the better your hardware, the worse this game will run.

In terms of actual gameplay, the main things that makes this game stand out from others in the franchise are Create a Style (Wherein you can edit almost any piece of furniture or clothing to be whatever color, pattern, or texture you desire, which is an INCREDIBLE feature) and the Story Progression, which I /LOVE/, to the extent that it makes it hard to go back to TS2 (Which I do prefer in a lot of respects otherwise) now that I'm accustomed to it. Watching your town grow and change is really nice, especially for Legacy challenges. But.. Oh good lord, the save bloat. Even with using every possible tweak, mod, etc, imaginable to help with performance and reduce bloat, my most recent Legacy challenge wound up bloating so much by generation 5 that the game refused to save anymore. I had to give in and download Onebeld's Regul Save Cleaner in order to trim it down and make it playable again. A lot of people turn off story progression just to avoid that issue, and I can't really blame them. 

Still, the animations are cute, this iteration of Create a Sim gives you a lot of freedom to work with in creating unique sims, and the traits are a really fun direction to take in terms of giving sims distinct personalities. I'd recommend this game any day over the Sims 4, even with its bugs, but if you're not interested in putting in all the work I alluded to above for the sake of Story Progression, traits, and Create a Style, then I'd just go with the Sims 2. It's still broken, but at least it's held together with duct tape vs the stale bubblegum keeping this game from falling to pieces.

Tldr: TS3 is the best edition of the game in my opinion. You'd have to grow up on TS4 or 5 to disagree. And also be a child.

Infinitely better base game than Sims 4. It's utterly hilarious that TS4 actually went free-to-play recently, while TS3 remains a purchased product. That alone should say something about the nature of EA (and the sales fee Steam dips their break into) and the future stake of The Sims series. Do not buy the newer games; everything they do, will, and can offer - older games offered for free, out the gate, no DLC or expansion packs. If you grew up on Sims 1 and 2, you will enjoy Sims 3. And if you don't, you never understood the core concept. Even TS3 is too newage and trendy for my tastes, and it's a fourteen-year-old game! TS4 is only 9 years old, but the modern trends of cash grabbing and EA thirst is clear. A sad, sad, backwards world when even say, Ubisoft, is a well-better-moraled company than Electronic Arts. Please. Stop entertaining EA's degeneracy of selling overpriced expansions for just about any feature the core game ought more than feature. Stop letting addons become a game's success. Buy a solid game for $20; do not claim a free game only to be baited into buying several short-change and phoned-in expansions packs to make a F2P experience more enjoyable. The Sims 4 is a trap, even more than The Sims 3 is definitely one. At least TS3 is a classic, and its collection seen as worthy and honorable in classical gaming. Rant over. Enjoy what you enjoy, but if it's a Sims game other than 2 or 3, you're wrong, and should have asked mommy or daddy before using the computer. Fact.
The gameplay is leagues better than TS4, with much less game-breaking errors and glitches (looking at you, My Wedding Stories!) and all-around a more fulfilling experience for the price tag.

My intro into the sims series was actually Sims 4, so I've gone back to Sims 3 after putting in 250 hours in 4. Just so you know there's no nostalgia behind this review. Also, TL;DR at the bottom!

Sims 3 is really freaking good in an old kind of clunky and chaotic way. I'm playing this [so far] on my 7 or 8 year old laptop so initial loading times are long, there's some frame rate hiccups and crashes but seeming only when using a monitor.

The biggest change that I knew and cared about going back from 4 to 3 was the separation of build and buy mode. I'd heard it was insanely annoying to load between the two but honestly... it's not that bad in my experience. It's about the same length of time as switching categories in Sims 4 for me, so about a second or two. Other than that... it's pretty good. The lighting is a lot worse than 4 and is a bit hard to properly light everything, and the overall graphics are... muddy. Everything is dark and almost over textured if that makes sense, but it's still possible to make good looking early to mid 2000's houses.

And that's where a lot of the joy comes from for me, this is truly a step back in time to the early to mid 2000's in all it's quesitonable glory. The Emo-over and guy liner, the *juicy* pants, the fur collared vests... it's glorious!

TL;DR. For me, the game runs fine, with only a few crashes. build buy is find seperated, and the color wheel is honestly a game changer in every way. The gameplay is the same, though a bit clunkier due to lack of mutlitasking, but it's still a very good game.

HOWEVER. I would recommend buying this on Origin/EA App as it's got 3 extra patches and the ability to buy 3 or 4 different worlds from Origin it's self rather than the in game MTX store, and they are not available on Steam. Also, the expansion pricing is very different and I think goes on sale more often? Overall all, amazing game and worth a check out.

This is still my favorite in The Sims series, but it also represents a turning point for the franchise. This was where The Sims stopped being a game and truly became a digital dollhouse.

Sims 3 has tons of DLC, most of which is pretty good, but not all of which play nicely with one another. There are some unfortunate dependencies which break the game entirely (depending on your operating system) if you don't install them in the right order. The content can become a bit overwhelming, with every young sim going to university all the time and random extended vacations to Egypt and spontaneously becoming a vampire... it's just a lot. Add in the stuff packs and all the community content... 

Oh yeah, all of it is micro-monetized like crazy. At the time I bought the game and DLC, it would have been easy to sink two or three hundred dollars into all of it... is it worth all that much? At the time, it was. Now, maybe not.

We now have the Sims 4 (or whatever the next version will be) and all of the above persists... Except with better visual appeal, fewer game-killing bugs and more expansive community integration with more customizable content.

I reccomend Generations, Pets, and Seasons, they are a necessity in my book.

There is also a pretty active modding community. You'll have no trouble finding more content to give your sims. Just remember, the more Custom content you add, the longer the loading times.

I'd also like to note the longer you play sims 3 on a save game, the more unstable it gets.

As a preface, I have a bias. 
The Sims 3 is one of my nostalgia games, along with Zoo Tycoon 2 and Spore. Some games I could play practically before I could walk.
The Sims 3 is without a doubt my favorite installment of the Sims Franchise.
It has more wack and severe optimization issues at times, but these problems can be helped with downloadable files you can find online to install into the package if you so wish.

The Sims 3 is in my opinion superior to The Sims 4 and does not inhibit qualities that prevent the player from having more fun and freedom with the game, and your sims will feel much more personable.
It does not tackle build mode with as much finesse, but has much more personalization with a color wheel and endless textures to choose from.

Similarly, as with Sims 4 the packs are needlessly expensive, I recommend Seasons, Pets, Showtime, and Supernatural for the Sims 3.

By far the best sims made, love the fact that it has so much to do and so much freedom. I love the aspect of the open world like game play, being able to have a whole open world town to interact with that has all sorts of businesses and other buildings is great. My favorite part of sims 3 is the fact you can be a business owner. It's fun to see your weekly check from it roll in, and being able to build your own/buy and edit and upgrade your business is so fun! I had one character who was top of the business career and over time I ended up buying everything in town and was rolling in 1m every week! The late night pack is super fun being able to be a celebrity and gain fame is also really cool. Another big one is having the option to own your own vehicle. Also on the sims 3 website there's an exchange tab where you can download all sorts of cool content people create and upload and that is reaaaally cool. For sure one of my favorite games and still playing in 2023!

Recently switched to the Steam version because I didn't want to deal with any more Origin/EA App bull. Best decision of my life. It runs a lot better and smoother, I don't have to deal with the bloat heavy launcher as I play, and I've just had a better experience with this version than ever before. There are some new bugs that I keep seeing in my gameplay from time to time that I didn't see too much from the 8 years of playing the Origin/retail version, but nothing too game breaking and that NRaas can't fix. But, I've also noticed that I can play with the same family for a much longer period of time before it gets too laggy to the point it's barely playable, which happened a lot to me when I played retail when I'd get around the in game 5-6 week mark. So if you are planning to play a save that you'd like to have for a long time, Steam is 100% the way to go. I would heavily recommend the Steam version of this game to anyone who is a new player, or an experienced player like me who hated Origin. I also recommend using NRaas mods/game fixes/smooth patch to help the game run smoother, which also works so much better than retail. In conclusion, if you're planning on playing The Sims 3, buy the Steam version over anything else, it will be such a better experience in the long run.

All The Sims game up to 3 have always held a special place in my heart, meanwhile 4 can go WooHoo itself with Malcolm Landgraab with their greedy monetization, expensive DLCs / expansion packs, and severely reduced features from the previous games.

The Sims 3 follows up from the previous game, while the previous game had solid emphasis with its memory, storytelling, CAW, wants and fears, and the setting up shop system; the third installment does fall short in some of the areas, they excel with its open world design, ditching loading screens altogether, though is not entirely avoided when travelling between worlds.

The game introduces the new moodlet system which pretty much determines the mood of your sim, compared to the previous game where mood is determined by your current sim's needs. They've also introduced the powerful CAS system (create-a-style) where in you can fully style any object or clothes in the game, which is honestly mind blowing.

Though the game has dropped some of the features from the previous game such as the good memory and fear system, they're replaced with inferior but not bad systems; fears have been dropped altogether, now only offering wish or wants, memories have less impact in the game and overall more clunky with a lot of insignificant memories clogging up the sim's memory. I do emphasize that although they've dropped or downgraded some of the system, it doesn't mean that the game has fallen off in terms of gameplay, as most of them are really not noticeable to the regular playerbase.

The game also provide excellent value for each expansion packs offered, much more feature-packed compared to the previous installments of the series, and definitely much more than the ridiculously overpriced, greedy, and lackluster expansion packs of The Sims 4. I could not say for the stuff packs as they were the first signs of how greedy EA can be, and it shows.

[b]tl;dr The Sims 3 is a good game where their strong point is their open world system, create-a-style, and excellent expansion packs[/b]

Gift-giving is gone. Cooking recipes require more skill from me than the AI - And I don't even know what to buy for some of them! Gardening takes up so much time, and I can't hire a Gardener anymore.
