The Sims 3, though sometimes buggy, is an amazing simulation game. There is so much to do, especially with the additional game packs and expansions. It is worth the investment (though I did get it when it had an awesome sale going on). Be prepared to spend hours on hours gaming away. The story lines and potential is endless.

You are much better off spending money on Sims 3 than 4, mainly because of price vs the content you receive. 

Sims 3 doesn't take you out of the experience with a loading screen to transition you out of your home, and into the city, the city is always loaded (this is a bad thing for performance in the long term but can be remedied with mods) 

Sims 3 has more worthwhile content packs, they add more content than their Sims 4 counterparts. 

Horses, Cars, Future Tech, Supernatural stuff, Ambitions, family units that feel like family. 

Sims 3 is also not constantly updated, so you won't have to check for mod compatibility every 2 to 3 weeks.

Sims 3 requires some finagling of the settings in order to get it to be semi playable today, with mods that smooth out the UI interactions.

You create "Sims" and play out their lives, careers, relationships, memories. There's tools the game provides you to build and decorate awesome houses and properties. Some argue this is where the series peaked.

Though, as an EA title, there's absurd pricing for the DLC, I recommend waiting for a sale and picking up 2 or 3 DLCs along with the base game, my choices were 'Seasons', 'Generations' and 'Pets' as these felt most impactful to the game. It'll still end up costing you more than the average 2009 game on sale though, because some companies don't want to price their games fairly.
You'll also likely need to install plenty of mods to get this game working properly again, those mods are thankfully free of charge.
I do recommend playing this game, but it's one that you should give up hope on having all content for unless you want to overpay, and even then the game is too unstable to enjoy it all properly.

You know how we all have that game that we have 500+ hours invested in and yet cannot wholeheartedly endorse to our friends?

Yeah, the Sims franchise is that for me. I've been playing since the original launched and have been hooked. Sims 2 and Sims 3 both brought really great features to the game. Sims 4 had a number of cool ideas, but the longevity of that game fizzled out for me and I keep finding my way back to #3. Much like coming home for the holidays, I can't seem to get out of committing my time to this. 

The reason this doesn't get a resounding recommendation is mostly for the quality of life issues. 

- There are dozens of expansions/content packs. If you wanted to own all of them, it would cost a pretty penny. 

- The game is glitchy and crashes like it gets paid to do so if you don't mod it with 3rd party mods. The number of times my game has crashed on me and I've lost hours of progress is way too high. There are mods to add an autosave feature, but the idea that that wasn't a native feature is mind boggling.

- It is an absolute resource hog. The base game was released in 2012. I am writing to you from 2022 on a brand new gaming PC and before I adjusted my VSync settings, it sounded like it was preparing to take off. 

On the other hand though, this game excels in many things. 
- Infinite customizability. I absolutely love how you can change the aesthetics on literally every item in the game, from color to pattern and material. Removing this from Sims 4 was a big loss for my playstyle.

- Character. I don't mean actual NPCs, but I love how much more expression the Sims you make have in this. You can actually see the individual animations as they go through life. The personality traits you assign them really guide their decisions and desires. Moodlets and emotions were a new feature from Sims 2 and it really helped to flesh out your Sim creations.

- Open world. The load screens might be a bit long up front, but once you are in you can traverse the entire map without pause. It is lovely to just wander over to the local bar or the neighbor's house without having to stop and decide if it is worth dealing with another load screen to get there.

So. Do I recommend this? I mean, I've been playing since 1999. 23 years as of writing this (good lord). So clearly I'm a Sims fan for life. However, this is a deep rabbit hole. Be ready to lose months, if not years of your life to building that perfect kitchen, or watching your legacy famly grow.


For the record, this is just mechanics. I haven't even touched on how bizarre some scenarios can get if you leave your Sim to their own devices. For example, one of my weirdest days one of my characters was struck by lightning, got arrested and when he got home, ended up abducted by aliens (when he was trying to run away from zombies). Like...what IS this game sometimes?
I really like how you can download custom content and have fun building homes and making sims :)

This game is the most ambitious Sims game of all.

It uses an open-world concept, not used before or since.

Also, I got this and not Sims 4 because, at the time I bought it, it was the only Sims game on Steam.

PROS:
Ghosts exist in the base game and have since launch, and they're pretty chill like they'd probably be in real life seeing as they're just dead people. This also means that death is not necessarily the end for a Sim.
If I'm feeling sadistic, I can be cruel to the Sims, though I can also care for them when I want them to do well.
Cheats make the game much more fun.
Can be modded, which can enhance the game in many different ways.
You can make your own story because the Sims speak gibberish.
Registering the base game rewarded me with a new world to play in.
Registering each Expansion Pack gets me additional content from the Sims 3 Store with no additional payment (registering Stuff packs doesn't do this but I did it anyway with the only stuff pack I have).
The base game used to cost $50 and the Expansion Packs used to cost $40, but both are now at a permanent discount such that they now cost just $20 each, which is the same as every Stuff Pack has always been (except for the Katy Perry one that's no longer being sold, which costed $30 when it was still being sold and probably costs way more secondhand due to being discontinued)

CONS:
Lags a lot, though editing config files the right way can make it far faster.
All of the content packs, both Expansion Packs and Stuff Packs, all cost $20, the same as the full game. It adds up quickly if you want all the content, including the Sims 3 Store content.
Sims 3 Store requires me to fork over even more money to get the majority of its content.
Ghosts can die of old age, though they just move onto the Netherworld (Sims afterlife) and permanently leave the game world.
Sometimes, the custom settings reset themselves.


Overall: 8/10 Would recommend.

Like masturbating: You get a sudden urge to play it, do so for a good 10 hours (okay maybe not a perfect 'simile'..... hehheh 'sim'ile) and realise what else you could have done with your life in that time. Its a huge timesink where you recreate an idealistic life while neglecting your own.

This would be a kind of half-hearted joke review as the game does have a very catharthic sense of fun all in all, but the excessive dlc definitely doesn't help endear the game, I have ambitions, Late Night and generations Expansions and the game feels heavily incomplete without them, the other ones are relatively passable but the 3 aforementioned EPs (alongside seasons) do feel neccessary.

 Given the fact I hear Sims 4 is even worse in this regard, I'm quite glad I skipped it, in fact, I always feel *heavily* reluctant to make any purchase for this game, I would say with the packs it is actually alot of fun, and very modular (unlike sims 4 at the moment).

 But irregardless, this game cannot get an honest review and still be positive, with such massive reservations i have about this addition to the series, especially since Origins blatantly neglects the steam version which can be easily broken, I did get my moneys worth out of it undeniably, but its almost a requisite more than entertainment at times, given the excessive cost.

If your a sim fan, you likely know a lot of these pitfalls and tricks, so here's what I found to be really good addons:
City Hub instead of neighbourhoods makes your sim feel in an expansive world
Ability to customize and paint outfits, furniture etc. is welcome
With the mentioned EPs, you get interactive careers added and a lot of new minigames and life goals for stuff like building robots, a true City as opposed to suburbs, Nightclubs and hot-spots to meet VIPs and get famous etc. 
Finally Generations heavily revamps all ages of your life and specific moments like weddings, Check the wiki for more details.

If your not a sims fan but are very interested in being one, I would pick up the base game first if you can get it for roughly 10 dollars max, but this is effectively a trial version, I have been steadily adding EPs year by year and the games cost has started to bloat, but indeed the game feels tellingly more complete, but at a cheap price, you can carefully evaluate it for yourself.

$400 of DLC and they never bothered fixing the numerous memory leaks and resource problems intrinsic to memories, story progression, or even the complexity of the DLCs interacting with each other. Even the modding community's most valiant efforts couldn't completely rectify a development model that I imagine looked like the NYSE trading floor in the late 20th century.

If everything worked I would call this a good game, but as it is, there was no reason to make a sequel to this outside of hocking buggy software to unwitting users. And what a surprise - the sequel was also a pile of shit.

A points I would like to make
-Base game isn't bare bones, unlike Sims 4
-While there's lots of DLC, not nearly as much pointless DLC unlike Sims 4
-Buying all DLC does not cost over $1000, unlike Sims 4
-World is very open, unlike Sim 4

If you're gonna get a Sims game on Steam, get Sims 3. Yes, it falls into the same trap of there being a lot of overpriced DLC, but it's still so much better than 4.

[b]⊕[/b]This iteration was a big leap in features, graphics and content. There is so much that can happen, and the city continues to move even if you're just watching the events of one household. Building homes has been drastically improved, and very gorgeous results can be obtained.

[b]⊖[/b]Cash shop features have snuck into the series, and it’s awful. Invasive even after the splash screen?? Why? The biggest thing for me is the music; Sims 1 had one of the best soundtracks out there, a series of incredible muzak renditions that filled the game with spirit. The overall soulless feel of this OST is worth mourning.

[b]✎[/b]Pricing for expansions is absolutely asinine. Do NOT buy any of this at full price. When DLC does go on sale, they go upwards to 75% off. Wishlist it and be patient. If you like to build worlds, this is the ultimate sandbox to play in. If you can step around all the microtransactions, you’ll find it’s a spectacular game worth your time. (I’ve put more time into S3, but they are not tracked. For reasons. :))

Alright so... Played this for a long long time on my PC, with very few DLCs...

I finally decided to take a dive and get all the DLCs I could.

It was a bad idea.

This game runs like absolute hot garbage with all the DLCs active, on my PC anyway, and from what I've found, it's not just me, and it's not just my PC, that have this issue.

I've tried every other optimization mod I could find, and it still just runs like a dying dog.

Requested a refund for the DLC bundle I got, but at the end of the day, if you can't use the DLC in a game, why even bother getting the game? Go try Sims 4 I guess.

Normally I'd even say, this is better than Sims 4... Worse than Sims 2... But considering the game is just so unoptimized for newer PCs, and the DLCs break the game more than it already kinda was... Pass on this. Save yourself the struggle.

The Sims 3 is a great way to pass the time. You can make your dream home, design your Sims however you want with the options available (no limit to colours, only to styles), and have your Sims live their lives however! You can let them fully automate themselves, but it's always good to keep an eye on them just in case something like a fire on the lot pops up. (Plus there are plenty of in-game popups pertaining to the lives of the Sims that you have to interact with regardless of Sim autonomy, so best to keep an eye on the game while your Sims live their lives!)

All in all, I highly recommend this game. I have far more hours than Steam would know about since I've had the game since before I had a Steam account.

Miraculously! Sims 3 packs are a lot more heftier than Sims 4 packs, S3Pets pack gave dogs, cats, horses, big&small birds, reptiles etc, (edit here: forgot to mention its world Appaloosa Plains and the animals items like bird cages and bird branches, if you have multiple branches in a room, birds will fly from branch to branch, think thats BRILLIANT and their's a good amount of cowboy looking house objects and BARN DOORS and also special unicorns). While S4Pets Pack gave just cats and dogs with their respective building items, clothes and world. S4 Vampires or Werewolves were two different packs; not that big of packs either but might be arguably better than what Werewolves and Vampires were in S3 Supernatural. I haven't played with any of these packs but Judging by what I've seen in other peoples play through's and such, I would personally say that Sims 3 Supernatural Pack was better! Not only are you getting Vampires and Werewolves but your getting Fairies, Zombies and Wizards! ALL in one pack. Zombies are more like the hypnotized Sims in S4 but if im remembering correctly, that was due to aliens and not a bite on the neck from a infected Sim.

Not to mention that Sims 3 and its packs are half it's price now since they released. But to give Sims 4 credit, the building and graphics are really really nice. Super easy to use in every way... EXCEPT THE FACT THAT SIMS 3 HAS SLIDERS FOR LITERALLY EVERYTHING!!!! You can even recolor wallpapers and objects like Rugs and Sofas!!! Besides that small little... GAME CHANGER, Sims 4 has better machanics. 

Even with that said, I'm gonna be playing Sims 3 with the Pets pack, Supernatural pack and probably a few others when I get bored of these ones, which I doubt will be anytime soon.

Something to note, Late Nights pack (Sims 3) has vampires too(why they did vampires in two different packs, idk?) but I heard it has some different stuff compared to Supernatural. Nothing  [i]game-breaking-ly[/i]  different or anything but [b]whatever[/b]

I played the Sims 3 a lot growing up, I remember my most memorable playthrough, my main sim died and I continued on as his still living brother, and kids. Then I got told I could bring back my main guy with the science area, I did that and he was back but as a ghost, then I found out how to make him not be a ghost anymore, then I found out how to make him effectively immortal with a special dish, then I just kept playing him and made him master every skill. Good times. Anyhow yeah i've played this game a lot over the years, not on steam by the by as this is a slightly more recent thing, but I'd still recommend it, it was a fun game with several aspects that I feel are better in this game than it's sequel. What are those aspects? No idea, I haven't played it or the sequel in at least a year or so, but I remember liking things about this one more than the 4th.

the sims 3 is a really fun game and a really nice entry in the sims series with endless gameplay, full customization and fun little details that are leaps and bounds ahead of the sims 4.

however, the game isn't properly optimized, the island dlc and back to the future dlc are not really worth it as they really clog the game up and just makes it run so slow, so you would have to rely on mods to have a proper experience. if you have a low end laptop it will definitely struggle with additional packs, so pick wisely when buying packs.

the base game is fun, and gameplay is fun when you carefully select what packs to play with, there is a 'bonus' store of content to purchase but ultimately it's not worth it to purchase said content. sadly, the create a sim, some of the build buy menus and even the start up menu is full of ads to entice you to purchase. a few worlds are locked behind these paywalls. 

overall, the sims 3 is a really fun game and has full customization options but is just plagued with lack of optimization. mods can fix this problem.

Despite EA's usual price gauging by over=priced expansion packs, this game remains my favorite Sims game, and my number 4 game of all time. Though the graphics aren't at the same level as the newer Sims 4, it has a lot more freedom. The towns are bigger. The dlc is cheaper. All the clothing, housing, and furnishings have many more design options. And it has a perk system. A what? Perk system. Choose your sims life goal. By fulfilling your sim's goals you get points to invest in perks that allow you to need less sleep or throw better parties. Then don't forget the mods. Thousands of them. This will run on a commodore computer if you can find one somewhere.

One of the most fun games I have eve played in my life. You're basically playing god and are able to do everything you want. You can create a family living a peaceful life or a crazy artist living with his mom in a shed with no toilets. Everything is possible and that's something I really enjoy. Especially when playing with mods you unlock absolutely everything and have full control over your Sims and the city you play in (NRaas).

The only thing that bugs me about Sims 3 is that it is very badly optimized. You could run this on a supercomputer and it would still lag really hard. Sometimes there is also this "Error 12" when trying to safe, which is really annoying as it forces me to restart the game and use an old save file. Luckily I installed a mod that reminds me to save every 10 minutes, which makes it less of a problem. but still very annoying.

Still, The Sims 3 has been a favorite of mine since I was a child and still is today.

PLEASE READ FOR 2022

Very Big problems with this game many you will eventually run into here is all the fixes

1. IF you have a 12 gen intel processer aka Alder Lake Cpu you will not be able to run the game and they havent fixed that ( I Had this exact problem and many of the problems will all look the same causing you to spend hours doing things that will not work)
The game will just go to launcher you click play and nothing happens 
now this problem will happen via if you installed the game at any point and now are reinstalling 
Simple fix just need to Registory Editor and fully wipe all sims 3 content

But for the Alder Lake Fix it requires a string of code to be writtin in an text document saved as a .ps1 and you run it with PowerShell you can find the thread with the code on eas message board thread look this up in google "Sims 3 won't open: Alder Lake (Intel 12th-gen) CPU" The code is written by a user named Mia

Essentially it will boot the game with one core and revert back once running she has fine tuned the script since december so it will work with orgin and all 12 gen cpus there was differnece in the code you used to have to write but no worries its fine tuned now.

But if you so happen to be a person where the game is not running for them i promise you there is a solution just dont give up but there is the list in a simpliar fashion of what it can be

1. Direct X9 Needs to be installed
2. 3.5 Net FRamework needs to be turned on
3. Hard wipe all sims 3 content from pc using cc cleaner and registory editor
4. IF you have 12 gen cpu must use script as said above

Those are all the conflicts i know of but again there is always a solution i spent personally 5 hours trying over and over until i found a thread by the wonderful sims 3 community in which through trial and error they found out 12gen cpus are a cause. If one proven solution doesnt work for you it is likely you need to move on and find another

It's so hard to recommend a lot of EA games because of the high price tag that they insist on keeping; it doesn't matter whether the game is old or not. If you plan to get the base game, then sure, get this. If you're willing to get DLCs, custom content (mods), etc. then maybe just get the Sims 4.

Even if the DLCs in the Sims 4 aren't as expansive as the ones in 3, the custom content by the community is phenomenal. It's also simply just the latest entry and (i think) goes on sale more than the Sims 3 does. To get the least ripped off, you DO NOT buy anything when it's not discounted (which is pretty obvious, but still).

Also, while the open-world feature in this entry is a nice addition (and is often brought up to bring down the sims 4), I don't feel like it warrants the performance buff - somehow I can get a consistent 60fps in modern games like Elden Ring but not this. To be honest, I think story progression is more important, which took them till THIS year to add to the Sims 4 in form of Neighborhood stories. Honestly, you can just get a mod that changes the way emotions work and call it a day - you shouldn't expect anything more until EA cares more for this IP.

live, laugh, love the sims 3

The game is extremely enjoyable with all the lives and scenarios that can play out. Compared to other Sims games it has a lot less in the base game than the Sims 2, however it will more than make up for that with the DLC and creator content available. As for how it compares to the Sims 4, besides a bit dated graphics the Sims 3 is superior in every category compared to what can easily be called a gutted cash grab with little inspiration less.

The main downsides to the Sims 3 that is very noticeable is the loading time, if you have an SSD it isn't that bad, but for anything else prepare to wait a long time to the point you question whether the game froze or not (it didn't just wait). Beside that, the price tag on the DLC and base game is way too high for the year it came out. The DLC is a big cash sink, but do you research and pick what is right for you if you only want a few. As other reviews have pointed out the Sims 3 was effectively abandoned by EA by the time the Sims 4 came out. If you play and notice bugs, glitches, or crashes there are community online fixes for most everything.

For years I've been a massive fan of the sims 3, and finally I was able to download and install the base game. I don't have a special gaming laptop and so I was obviously worried that it wouldn't work or that I wouldn't have the same experience as other players. However, base game sims 3 runs perfectly with very little lag. I love the fact that it's open world, unlike sims 4, so the game doesn't feel limited. There is so much to do in base game alone, without all the DLC. After playing sims 4 for two years and then coming onto sims 3, sims 3 has definitely become my favourite. I would say the only disappointment with the game would be some of the DLC. If you're playing on a normal laptop then you are limited to how many or what DLC you can buy and it does slow the game up a little bit. Overall I recommend the sims 3

First of all, I just want to start by saying. This is an EA game, in by that I mean, I always find most of these games to be too expensive or just a tad bit overpriced, especially within the sims franchise. The sims 3, is by far the laggiest game I have ever experienced with all of the other sims games. (To be clear, I have played 2-4.) BUT out of all of the sims games, I always find myself coming back to this one, there are so many different lag fixes for this game, ones that don't even require you to install mods. Those fixes help A L O T. I was able to get DLC like Island Paradise to work perfectly. You do not need all of the DLC to get a lot of content for this game, I don't even have all of them just a few that I know I would like and use the most, it should be fairly easy to see what you would enjoy and wouldn't, and if you don't have an idea there are a lot of content creators on youtube who still play the sims 3. I have never had any trouble with the graphics of this game, I actually don't even mind the default or older look, you just need to know how to get the perfect graphic settings, get over the some what- pixelated edges of the clothes (It really isn't that noticeable unless you are looking for it.) and try your hardest to ignore how greasy the hair looks in CAS (Or be like me, and download hair replacements.)

Great game! I never got bored because the gameplay is pretty addicting in a good way. There's plenty of customization for your sim, such as traits, hairstyles, and color. It's literally like living another life to escape from reality which is what really interested me. What really makes Sims 3 stand out is it's open world. I never got any frame rate drops because I have a good computer, but even if I did I would still see the open world as a highlight. It makes you F E E L like your living another life. Also, because this game was released in 2009, I have lots of nostalgia for that because I really enjoyed my younger years. Graphics have definitely aged though. Doesn't bother me that much, but hey I'm still downloading mods to improve the graphics.

The only negative thing I have to say about sims 3 is that the expansion packs are so expensive, and that some of them should be in the base game already. For example: Seasons, Ambitions, and Pets. Why do they cost as much as the game itself!? I can tolerate Ambitions and EVEN Pets, but SEASONS!? WHY!? During the 2022 summer sale I was hoping that sims 3 and it's dlc were on sale but NOPE. And so, I only bought the base game. 

9/10 should of made dying it's own expansion pack for $19.99

After years of playing and loving Sims 3 I've finally had enough. Too many glitches and problems with this game, issues between Steam, Origin, and EA in having to frequently reinstall previously downloaded DLC packs, having them disappear from the game, etc. 

My game is up to date. I operate on a computer that more than meets the system requirements to run this. I don't have space or video issues that should interfere with the game - yet it continues to run into these problems. 

EA and Origin have been zero help on this issue.

Perhaps one of the most frustrating aspects is the fact that it requires 3 separate accounts and EA & Origin consistently sign me out (despite being set to keep me logged in). It means I have launch and relaunch with each play. After spending close $800.00 in the last few years on the game, DLC packs, and in-game purchases this is absolutely not worth it. Not giving EA or Origin another dime of my money.

I really enjoy this game. As always, it's fun being able to do literally anything with your Sims (as it is in almost all Sims games). The new additions such as the open loading screen-free world and Create-A-Style are simply revolutionary and are very welcome additions. 

I do have some gripes with the game though. While the Create-A-Sim is certainly very detailed, I  find it difficult to make my Sims look like myself. That might be a me problem, but I've also found that some of the Sims I see in my worlds also look a bit like hodgepodge. The hairstyles also definitely didn't age too well, and I can't guarantee that you'll find one that will fit your Sim. If you're really into CAS and house-building, I suggest downloading stuff packs or custom content from the exchange.

I also found that the game can get a bit boring or tiresome without expansion packs or new worlds. After a generation of Sims I kind of lose the motivation to continue the family. The Sim lifespans are also too short for my taste, but with Generations, these spans become customizable.

While I do have a lot to say about my dislikes about the game, I do genuinely enjoy playing through a generation of Sims. These flaws aren't really enough to make me dislike The Sims 3 and don't have that significant of an effect on my opinion. Recommended👍

As a veteran Sims player - whatever the hell that means - this is my Sims game of choice. The only reason I choose this over Sims 4 is how the expansions are priced and split up. In the Sims 3 it feels less like EA is trying to absorb your wallet with the expansions, but there are some noticeable downsides in build mode and create-a-sim compared to Sims 4. If those are extremely important to you, I would recommend the Sims 4 over this if price per unit content isn't as important to you. As someone who loves building unique houses from scratch though, the Sims 3 can still satisfy your needs but it can be far more challenging to do so.

And as always, regardless of if it's Sims 3 or 4, only buy these games on sale. Don't support EA more than you have to.

The Sims 3 has always been a ton of fun for me, but it is ridiculous how much the game's expansions cost with how old it is now. There are some aspects of the game that I really love, mainly with the more realistic aspects of the game (i.e. not any of the supernatural aspects), but I've heard those are pretty fun to play with. I only recently stopped playing because I've been on a Sims 4 kick, which it is ridiculous how often the Sims 4 is on sale versus how often the Sims 3 is. It's part of why I switched because the Sims 4 packs, when on sale, are somewhat more cheaper for me to buy them (the bundle when there are sales, specifically). Anyway, don't get this game if you aren't ready to spend money on the extra content that makes gameplay either more realistic or fantasy-like. I mean like really ready, because the extra content is like this: Seasons (for holidays, seasonal weather, extra clothing option, additional interactions and items, etc), University (kinda a new world/town, degrees, traits, clothes, skills, etc), Generations (more interactions with kids, items, traits, etc), and, well the list goes on really.

I've played all the mainline Sims games, and i gotta say, this one's definitely my favorite.

Of course people are going to give it flack for being unoptimized, but as long as you install the SmoothPatch mod (which is essential at this point), you're gonna get fast loading and stable performance.

This game let's you customize every little aspect about, well, everything. From the texture and color of your clothes, house, car, and items, to even bulldozing the entire town and building new stores and houses from scratch. This is the ultimate sandbox to mess around with, better than any other entry in the Sims series.

Sure the Sims may not be as human as in the Sims 2, but i can forgive it for having better objective-based gameplay than Sims 2 (in my opinion), there's plenty of other tweaks they gave to the AI, and while these creatures certainly aren't human compared to Sims 2, they're still fun to look at and mess around with however you want. The imagination's your limit

I highly recommend getting the Generations expansion too, you may find there are some things you wish to do that aren't available, more often than not it's available in Generations (which should have been stuff included in the base game to begin with)

Otherwise, this is a great building game with goal-based missions and lots of creativity and paths to explore, you'll sink plenty of time into this game.

A fun game for its time, but honestly Sims 4 runs better control-wise and of course graphics-wise. I still think this is a good game, but unfortunately any glitches still in the game have been left unfixed; though that is mainly in the expanded packs.

Still beats Sims 4 tenfold.

Pros: The Sims 3 is definitely an improvement from the Sims 2 and is, in my opinion, the best of all 4 games. The lore is deep and families from the Sims 2 are back. There is so much customization when it comes to building lots and adding clothes to your sims. The game also has music from real artists translated into Simlish for the simmer's pleasure. There are a ton of personality traits, aspirations, and I love the biography option. The player has so much creative choice and there are quite a few unique features that other sims games don't have. Sims react more realistically to life events than in the Sims 4 and it's an open-world, so you're not staring at a loading screen every time your sim leaves the house. The build and buy modes have a wider variety of textures with more customization, angling, and furniture. The settings menu itself has a lot of customization and preferences to offer, including changing your sims' lifespans. If you have the pets expansion, you can actually play as your pets, unlike in the Sims 4 where pets are NPCs. The game offers a tutorial for new players to help them navigate it's many features and also provides a small guidebook. You can also look up tips online. There is a social feature where you can message, friend, and like the posts of other simmers as well as post your own content. As a writer, I sometimes use this game to act out my stories and bring them to life.

Cons: The game isn't complete without buying expansion packs. This has always been a problem with the sims games as players have been urged from the very beginning to spend money on additional content. The game is also very glitchy and hasn't been updated in years due to the fact that EA is instead focusing on more recent projects (like the Sims 4.) The base game itself doesn't have a wide variety of clothes and hair styles and can get boring after a while. I've had to reinstall the game more than once due to bugs. The quality of the game is typical of it's time, but is considered outdated and low now. The interaction between the sims and objects could also use some improvement, especially since sims have a larger space bubble and therefore can't walk as freely, unlike in the Sims 4 where they can pretty much go wherever they want. The game also uses sliders instead of clicking and dragging, but this is mostly because that kind of feature hadn't really been introduced in video games yet and was a very new concept when this game was released. If you're a fan of sliders, this may be a good thing, but if you prefer clicking and dragging, you won't see any of that here. The sims' fears from the Sims 2 don't exist in this game. The game stores memories and life events, but the sims can't talk about them and are not as affected by them as they are in the Sims 2. It's also harder to play without using a mouse.

Tips and side-notes: Although this game is available on console, I recommend downloading it on PC as the controls are a lot easier and it'll be easier to type commands as well as other texts. When installing mods, test them out as sometimes files can conflict and become corrupted. You can view your downloaded content in the launcher under "Downloads." If you need technical support, since EA no longer provides it for this game, I recommend diving into the sims forums. Often times you'll find people experiencing a similar problem and there are experts who can help you out. I also recommend getting expansion packs while they're on sale. If you like the game, there are a number of Discord servers you can join that also provide technical support.

Overall, this is a good game and I love it. Cheers-

Edit: so the game randomly won't run for me anymore. I've tried everything from reinstalling the game, updating my drivers, and I've tried to uninstall custom content but the uninstaller doesn't work either. It just shows me a black screen and then crashes. I've also tried "run without custom content" and that doesn't work either. I've tried every forum and no one has been able to help me.

After having consistently played this game for over a decade, I can truly say it's a treat for anyone who likes the odd, somewhat frustrating, and unpredictable nature of in-depth life simulators. I wish I could convince all those who have only tried the restrictive tragedy that is The Sims 4 to give this old beauty a try. The modding/custom content scene is alive and well, so fear not EA's stylistic choices with content. Highly customizable, so that from a Sim's clothing to their furniture, they are a real individual. Endless gaming possibilities with the expansions (all of which I recommend with the exception of Ambitions) and community challenges. Honestly, I still haven't seen everything the game has to offer, and I look forward to each new discovery. If you've never played this game before, get Seasons and Generations with it, but nothing else to start with. The best explorative experience comes when you add the expansions slowly, and give yourself time to delve into what each one brings to the game. If you buy many at once, you will be overwhelmed by additions and look at nothing thoroughly.
I won't ever be done playing The Sims 3, and neither should you.

Sims 3 is still my nostalgic favorite. My preferred playstyle is running one household long-term, and 3 was the only one to really cater well to that. It's still unimaginable to me that EA/Maxis went back to the antiquated loading screen for travel to neighboring lots in Sims 4 after they effectively turned 3 into an open-world game that was actually worth exploring.

Unfortunately, when I go back and play it now its age definitely shows in some disappointing ways and I can't quite get immersed in it like I used to. And the prices are unconscionable for a nearly 15-year-old game (I managed to snag it on one of the rare instances it was actually on sale at an acceptable discount, though I still have a number of the discs around... erm... somewhere).

So my recommendation is predicated on two things: you, too, still have the deep nostalgia for what The Sims was a decade ago (and earlier) AND you can get it at a good price (like... Sims 4 is $5 most of the time, and they still want $20 for 3, c'mon, man 😂).

It's also worth noting, as of this writing in mid-2022, Maxis appears to be ramping up hiring again, which suggests a Sims 5 announcement is probably likely within the next year or so, AND Paralives is still in development, and if you're an optimist you could hope one or both of those titles could tap into what made Sims 3 so beloved, but modernize it and make it feel like something worth playing today.

A guy can dream, y'know.

If my computer was able to run this game without it crashing because of how outdated it is, I would still only play the Sims 3. This game got so much right in ways the Sims 4 has not been able to replicate, let alone surpass. 

Despite the improved graphics the Sims 3 expansion packs, items diversity, and design tool remain unrivaled. Whereas the Sims 4 chose to be more socially interactive and complex. The Sims 3 still remain the better of the two based on content and navigational ease. 

I don't have high hopes for the Sims 5 considering it'll likely be all about social media interactions, rather than world expansions and design portfolios.

I love this game for many reasons, one of which is the freedom on how to play.  This game has a versatile range of play styles, such as giving your sim a good home, letting them go to college, etc.; or conducting experiments to see which of your sims die first when left with no food, etc. I've had this game for years, and you can definitely start over with unlimited cheats, or with a challenge, and more! The only con I can think of is that the DLC are ridiculously priced (some of which maybe should have been included in the base game). I really don't think it is worth it forking over your money on DLCs for full price, and instead, would recommend buying the DLC only on sale. Overall, this is a great game and I personally like it more than Sims 4. But each their own, you know?

I am an offline gamer, so the hours on record do not show how much I love this game.  I have played for 100's if not 1000's of hours over the last couple of years, and I'm sure I will continue to rack up many, many more.  It is the only Sims I possess - I was interested but cautious about Sims 4, and it looks like I was right to be!  If you like 'playing God' with the family/community of your choice, Sims 3 is all you need, extension packs definitely not required.  I did 'flirt' with Pets, but now I stick to 8 characters and lead them through their lives...

Highlights:
1. The town and the characters therein are fully customizable.  You can switch from household to household, level up characters and then merge households to get your perfect group.  It's a minor disappointment that you cannot introduce a new life goal after one is achieved - but you can introduce a new character!
2. NRAAS Overwatch and Error keep the game running smoothly.
3. It doesn't take too long to amass enough 'money' to build the house of your dreams.
4. Electronic Arts may have disappointed many fans, but Sims 3 is all you need to have lots and lots of fun.
5. There always seem to be new challenges to work at.
6. Although just a base game, it is completely addictive, remeniscent of Playstation's 'Kiss you life goodbye' ads!

I spent $90 on all the DLC for this game when it was on sale. 

I also had to spend an hour on half a dozen different websites downloading and installing half a dozen optimization mods (and that's just the basic ones) because this game hangs and/or crashes frequently. The developers kludged the base game and its expansions together. Why isn't all of this available on the Steam Workshop?

I want to enjoy this, but EA Games, while they make a lot of content, make it very hard to enjoy it all at once. Props to the community for doing what the developers should have done 15 years ago. 

EA's adversion to including anything like religion mechanics also factors into my review - and this applies to all versions of the Sims, retroactively. Most other social simulators feature religion in some fashion; Rimworld has it as a DLC. Going Medieval features it natively. Dwarf Fortress added it eventually. Some of these games may be uglier, but if they can make religion work, pretty stupid that EA won't add fantasy religions, generic religions, abstractions of contemporary religion, etc...

i’ve been a massive sims fan for YEARS. i’ve only ever played the sims 4, but i’ve been isolated for this past weekend because i was exposed to covid, so i decided to go a little crazy and get the sims 3. as it was downloading i was like, this is such a waste of money. it’s going to be exactly the same as sims 4 and i’m going to regret this purchase. i did not regret this purchase. oh my god, it is so much better. even just the BASE GAME has so many more options and customization, thanks to create a style. honestly, i was really surprised to find just how much more the game has to offer even without expansion packs that are almost necessary for the sims 4 to be any fun.  the sims 3 is the better game. from the traits to the build mode, it really takes the cake. the attention to detail is awesome, and it just feels so much more.. carefully? made. your sims actually turn off the lights when they go to sleep, and their beds become unmade.. the sims 3 is awesome and i can't believe it took me so long to give it a chance.

They screwed up the franchise after the first one. 
Also, EA realized the power of DLC's as a way to milk the cow at ridiculous (and expensive for the user) levels. 
So they thought: "why not making a basic game, then charge full price for it to players and then we can sell them the game in dropplets called "DLC's". Hell! we can even charge them for non-game-mechanics like dresses or haircuts for their dolls."
I absolutely love this game, no matter what, I always come back to play it, even after playing sims 4 I still come back to the sims 3 just for the game play .

It's very good, but unfortunately that's a statement that comes with a lot of qualifiers. It has some significant issues - it's laggy, it doesn't close properly, the base game is a little bare - but despite these I still consider it my favorite mainline Sims game. The open world, which is still the series best idea to date, was removed from The Sims 4. If that was not the case, it would be a closer contest, but as-is, The Sims 3 is still the top of the heap in spite of its (admittedly significant) problems.

If you do plan on getting the game, a word regarding DLC: There are a few DLC that I would say are almost required for the "full" experience, those being Generations and Ambitions, which both add mechanics/features that are sure to enhance the experience of any playthrough. After that I would HIGHLY recommend Pets, Supernatural, University Life, and Seasons. These are all fantastic DLCs, but they're contextual enough that not every player necessarily "needs" them to fully enjoy the game (for example if you don't think you'll want to play with pets much, or worry too much about the teen/young adult stages, then you might be fine skipping Pets or University respectively).

TLDR: fantastic game that needs some fixing up to be truly flawless, buy some of the DLCs for sure, the rest are pretty much up to you

I know everyone has their favorite Sims game and this is definitely my favorite one for many reasons! The main aspect that I love is that it is open world so there are no loading screens to wait ages for. I also like that other sims in the world actually have personalities and lives (unlike The Sims 4 in my opinion, although some updates have improved this). The expansion packs are so good in this game too and I think they are well worth the money. This game is just so lovable and so much personality that you can't not love it. One con is that the clothing and furniture are a bit outdated, but CC can be downloaded to fix this. Also, some people prefer the more cartoony look of TS4 sims, however, I like the more realistic looking sims in TS3.

The Sims 3: Crie o mundo perfeito com personalização completa na ponta dos dedos. Refinar personalidades e ajudar a cumprir destinos.

Brinque com a Vida.

Crie as vidas que você sempre quis!
Pronto para viver uma vida mais livre e criativa? No The Sims™ 3, você pode deixar suas fantasias correrem soltas enquanto projeta seu mundo ideal. Comece com o seu Sim, refinando cada forma, cor e traço de personalidade até encontrar a pessoa exata que lhe agrada. Projete a casa dos seus sonhos, mas não deixe que uma grade o limite; coloque, gire e empilhe móveis e paredes livremente e para o conteúdo do seu coração.
Quando o “trabalho duro” terminar, é hora de ser um mentor. Guie o caminho do seu Sim pela vida, desenvolvendo uma carreira, encontrando amor e perseguindo sonhos e desejos. Passar tempo com amigos e familiares é tão importante quanto dominar a pintura ou acumular conhecimento.
Leve as coisas para o próximo nível e grave filmes das aventuras do seu Sim e compartilhe-os com a comunidade cada vez maior e próspera. Com um enorme catálogo de pacotes de expansão e objetos divertidos para descobrir, não há fim para as possibilidades esperando por você. Tudo começa aqui; sua aventura espera!

This is one of those games that I'm hesitant to recommend--not because it's a bad game (in fact, quite the opposite), but because it's plagued with a few unfortunate setbacks, the likes of which aren't going to be fixed any time soon.

The biggest of these setbacks is the fact that the AI pathing in this game is absolutely horrible. Whenever a Sim gets stuck (and they WILL get stuck), the entire game will freeze as it tries to fix the sim's path. What this means for you is sitting at a frozen screen incessantly for minutes at a time. Luckily, there is a mod that can help mitigate this problem--Nraas's Overwatch--but it won't completely solve the issue, so be aware of this problem before you decide to buy.

With the mod, the game becomes much more bearable, to the point where you can actually enjoy it! The Sims is considered one of the best "life simulators" for a reason. It's a unique game that has carved its own niche out in the gaming world. If you enjoy creating your own stories, constructing a house you've always dreamed of, or simply carrying out your most sadistic desires by killing the sims you create, then The Sims 3 might be the perfect game for you.

[h1]My Rating: 8/10[/h1]

I do not know how many hundreds, if not thousands of hours I sunk into this game, and Sims games in general. This was the last installment of the franchise I purchased with all of the expansions. I purchased the base Sims 4 title, but did not like it at all. 

This is my favorite in the franchise. It took many years to finally get all of the expansions, but even after all of these years, it is still a whole lot of fun. Although dated, and has its limitations, because it is so old.

As for the gameplay, it can get very laggy with all of the DLCs. So to pick up the pace, just pick the ones you like best. Otherwise, it is very fun! Things can get very overwhelming very quickly, but that's half the fun. It's also a kick in the pants to challenge yourself. Say, the homeless challenge, or try to have the maximum number of people in a household with little money. The list is endless. Although getting extremely rich in the game is not hard at all, so that can get boring at times.

Like the other Sims titles, DLC is very expensive. This goes on sale once in a while, but it is still very expensive. Unless you are into these kinds of games, get the base game before jumping in with both feet.

THE SIMS... What's there not to like about the Sims? The only thing you can't do is what you haven't thought of yet. It's a classic, going on almost 25 years. This is the best version of the Sims hands down. Don't bother with the sims 4. This is it right here. There's unparalleled detail and customization. You can customize any object to be any color or any pattern. Do you want a table made of fabric? A dress from metal? You can do that. Do you want that couch but in orange with lime green cushions? You can do that too. Want to make a witch family that lives in a castle with extensive gardens and fountains? Yup. A modern city celebrity that moonlights as a guitar performer in the subway.. that's possible too. Your imagination is the limit here, and well, your processor for high quality details but that's beside the point. You should absolutely buy this game it is my favorite of all time.

I initially purchased a disc copy of The Sims 3 back in the early 2010s, and played the Sims 3 for God knows how long. More recently I picked up the Steam-version along with the DLC Collection off of a sale, and whilst I do enjoy finally having access to the various expansions, and whilst they do bring fun things along with various features (such as the weather & seasons system in The Sims 3: Seasons), they are hardly necessary for an enjoyable experience.

I see myself spending countless more hours with the game, probably reaching the three-digits by the end of the year. After all, The Sims 3 is arguably the best game of the Sims-franchise, not to mention being considerably cheaper when compared to it's successor, The Sims 4, which in turn lacks in many aspects, and is not an enjoyable experience unless you are ready to pay up.

Alas, the Sims 3, particularly in terms of the Steam version, has some issues Electronic Arts has fixed on the Origin version, but left in the Steam version. If intentional, I cannot say, but the fix is rather easy. I have published a Steam-guide for addressing these issues, so you don't have to wander in the internet for an hour.

Personally, this is my favorite Sims game. I never played the PC versions of any other Sims games except for this one. In fact, most of the Sims games I’ve played are on console. That being said, I love this version of the game more than the PS3/X360 version of the game. But let’s go over some of the good and bad things about The Sims 3.

The game is very fun, and much easier than past iterations of the Sims. There’s lots of ways to interact with the town, and your household, and that expands tenfold with the more DLC you purchase. However, this doesn’t mean you should go and buy every DLC imaginable, as it has a tendency to get a little chaotic and laggy. Fortunately, DLC can be toggled off on Steam, and the bigger DLCs tend to introduce settings to control the chaos. 

Another issue I have with this game is how long it takes to actually get into the game. There’s 2-3 loading screens you must sit through (though you have the option of interacting with one of them) before you’re finally in a save. Maybe it’s because my system is on the lower end and lacks power and an SSD, but I find that it takes 5-10 minutes before I’m finally in. 

Technically problems aside, it’s still a really fun Sims game. And unlike The Sims 4, this game doesn’t require you to install Origin to play. All and all, I highly recommend, but I advise against playing on lower end computers.

For a game released in 2009, there’s a lot of fun to be had. The gameplay loop is self-explanatory, create your Sim (or Sims), and watch them live their lives in a fictional version of reality. In terms of towns, you only have Sunset Valley. If you only own the base game. Via expansion packs or some Store content, There’s even more towns to choose from. It also has an open world, meaning you can say hi to your neighbors without a loading screen getting in the way. 

However, here’s where problems start to crop up. The more content you have in your game, the worst your game performs. What makes this even worst, is that the game doesn’t recognize modern GPUs. [i](same goes for modern CPUs)[/i] So, you’re gonna have to fix that yourself. If not, the game will stutter like crazy, and may crash on you, and since there’s no auto-save, I’ll let you fill in the blanks.

The game also aged very poorly visually, meaning you’ll be looking at very stiff animations, and plastic looking Sims. There’s also many issues that the devs didn’t address through the 5 years of support [i](2009-2014)[/i]. Some of these issues can be quite devastating if you’re doing a fan challenge or just playing it normally. Thankfully, mods are available to make playing the game less painful, but mods can only do so much to fix fundamental issues. Did I mention that the game is super buggy?

I do have nostalgia for the game, but I can’t let that blind me from the game core issues. You’ll have to jump through so many hoops just to play it on modern hardware. But if that’s not a problem for you, give it a shot. Do I think it’s a good starting point for the series? Yes and no. “Yes” because it’s very easy to jump in (along with mods), and “No” because of its many problems. Plus, the expansion packs and stuff packs are far too expensive. (CDN$ 26.99) So I’d say wait for a sale. 

[b]If you want a starting point, play The Sims 4. That game may have its own set of issues, but at least there’s still some fun to be had with the game.[/b]

Did you know sometimes the Sims 3 menu keeps running in the background even after you've exited the game, making it look like you've played the game far longer than you actually have? I thought that was interesting.

PROS:
   - fully customizable:  sims, houses, objects
   - get invested in your sim's lives
   - if you love Sims its the cheaper alternative to Sims 4 ($1400 for entire game)

CONS:
  - $$$, ~$500 for entire game = wait for a sale
  - very buggy with no support
  - many performance issues

Sims is one of those games that is enjoyable to get lost in.  Its absolutely fun customizing everything from your sim's appearance, to the housing they live in, to the objects that fill it.  You can get invested in your sims families and experiences and try out lots of different jobs and experiences.

One thing that is really important to note about it is: its a REALLY expensive experience. This makes it not very accessible to the common person.  At about $500 for the entire game, most of us don't or can't buy all of the packages.  You really have to wait for a sale to try out the pieces you are interested in.  That said it is still a LOT cheaper then Sims 4 at ~$1300 so you'll find people will still be playing Sims 3 for years to come.

Some of the packages like the University, Island Paradise and World Adventures have huge bugs and performance issues.  This is unfortunate because the content in them was fun.  You have to be careful installing DLC out of order because this makes it worse.  You might see your game stall, crash, or just make certain regions inaccessible or wipe out your progress.   I had one instance where I had just finished designing my home only to have the game crash and I lost hours of progress.  There is no autosaving. When I play I find myself avoiding some of the more buggy content.  Obviously since current development is on Sims 4 you won't see a lot of bug fixes.  You're pretty much stuck in the As-Is category.  So its a take it or leave it experience.  

Overall I wouldn't recommend putting money out on Sims 3.  Try some new indie life sim games instead.  They're a lot cheaper and less buggy.  They may not be as complete, but if you can't play the content because its buggy what's the difference?  If you can get a really good sale deal try it but remember you are taking a risk with University, World Adventures, and Island Paradise.

I owned all of The Sims 3 packs on disc, and now that disc is (sadly) going out of fashion, I was SO EXCITED when I saw that Steam had the whole collection on sale. My wife bought it for me for Valentine's Day, and I was immediately sent into a wave of nostalgia and happiness that was brought up from the countless hours I put into this game.

While the graphics may not be the best, the game play is an absolute deal breaker when it comes to The Sims as a series. You can actually see your Sims when they travel, and they can go to countless destinations and have way more experiences than any other Sims game. Out of the entire Sims series, 3 will forever be my favorite and will always have a place in my heart.

Don't bother with any other Sims, this one is it. 
1. I love that the world is open, not instanced like in Sims 4. This means so many relationships are interactions are happening at the same. 
2. Love the customization. A couch can be made to look like a sleek leather one or a tacky animal print. It changes the mood and personality of your houses and this level of customization isn't around in future Sims. 
3. Love the expansions. Especially college, seasons, generations, and pets. Those all add so much to the game with things to do, places to go, and goals to accomplish. 
4. Love the progression. Skills are obtainable but it feels like you earn them. For example, you can become great at gardening but to have master gardener it really takes a Sims lifetime. Making it take a long amount of time and effort to get top skills makes the characters feel unique when they obtain them. 
5. Fun mods. Can download lots of mods to keep it fresh, running well, and to include more furniture and outfits than you ever dreamed of.

Don't fall into the trap like I did. I can't tell you how many hours and dollars this game has absorbed from me over the years. Keep in mind that I owned the CD version of this when it first came out, so double the hours that I have played on Steam.... 

This game is like the perfect drug dealer. It gives you just enough so that you want more. You shell out dollars for DLC just to get a little MORE. You spend hours on mods and stores just to get a little MORE. An expansion comes out and you throw dollars at it because you want MORE. A new location, a new magic well, a different profession. You want MORE and you throw dollars at it to make it make you happy.

The thing is though, you will never be satisfied. Each piece is like half an apple. Just enough to keep you going, but never enough to satiate your hunger. You can spend a psychotic amount of dollars on DLC that are extremely over priced. Half of the store 'premium' content doesn't even work (I am looking at you gondola). You search around and find mods to band-aid the bumps and bruises. But now, most all of the advice is from 2012 so it is a coin-toss as to whether or not it still applies. I am not going to say that this game isn't entertaining, that would be a lie. But ask yourself, does EA really have your best interest in mind?

Every Sims game has been more expansive yet somehow worse than the one before. From the brilliant, funky early-entries, with stunning effort put into entirely remade console versions, all the way up to whatever bland shrugfest Sims 4 is; the initial magic and genius that Will Wright lended to this series has been diminishing with every new title. For a long time, all it's been is a way to squeeze buckets of cash out of kids.

But, in the end; just because 3 is better than 4, doesn't mean 3 is all that good. The Sims 3 is hampered by aimless complexity, with no attempt to streamline its swelling feature-list into something measured and coherent. It was initially shrugged off, too; and has only gained these "glowing reviews" after Sims 4 proved to be even worse.

I guess context is contextual, isn't it?

Had to properly cleanse all previous sims files, and then the new installation began properly. Couple of old windows files needed, and we were away.
I do recall that this game did not run well if you loaded up too many expansions, so we will see what 10 years of technical advances can manage, but honestly expecting a crash now I've seen how long the save process is.

I recommend you only buy this as the collection bundle when it goes on sale. I got all the expansions for $99au. Do not pay $30au for one stuff pack at full price, those prices are ridiculous considering how old the game is and how terribly it runs.
If you aren't buying the full collection, don't buy any stuff packs at all. Tumblr and Sims Resource have better custom content for free.

https://store.steampowered.com/bundle/1247/The_Sims_3_Collection/

Overall, it's an iconic game, I've been playing it since it first came out when I was a kid and it never gets old. It gets a recommendation over TS4 any day. 
So much more content and depth overall with the right expansions, its a much better experience. The game runs like shit but if you spend the time following some guides for performance, bug fixing, cleaning saves, and downloading NRass mods its entirely playable. Although it still has its certain issues, and is prone to crashing, so if that seems like it would be a problem for you I would skip it.

TS4 has loading screens opposed to TS3 open world, which = better performance for TS4, but completely ruins the flow of the game for me and I would take the instability of TS3 open world over the loading screens. It's more of a personal preference, but 3 is still a better game overall, no question.

If you are only wanting to pick up one or two expansions instead of the whole collection and don't know which ones you should go and check out Lazy Game Reviews Sims 3 playlist, he covers everything pretty thoroughly.

What is there to say about The Sims 3 that hasn't already said? I absolutely love it and is probably one of the last great simulations EA has released. It streamlined some of the bulkier mechanics of The Sims 2, it added badly needed depth to the franchise and the amount of shit you can do is simply INSANE. In comparison, The Sims 4 is a cheap imitator, a shallow, dumbed down version of it's former self. 

The Sims 3 was also when their DLC really started to get out of hand, fortunately, I feel like there are only a few of the expansions that you really need to properly enjoy The Sims 3, so that's a plus.

installed this to compare Sims 3 to Sims 4 - wish I hadn't. I blame youtube :steamfacepalm:

Pro: Sims 3 is great for storytelling. The open world is really immersive, global story progression brings it to life, NPC and sim autonomous actions are fun and surprising. You always want to dig for more, see what else your Sim can do, what else the world has to offer. Racoons, deers, horses, birds, whut! Control of house pets makes you feel like you know them better. So many personality types, available themes. It's hard to get bored. And, of course, the style customization in build/buy is incomparable.

Con: Sims 3 really really really fails on the UX, for me that breaks the same immersion and drags game play. The clunky early-2000 game interface could be overlooked if not for the genuinely buggy build mode interactions (just adding a window can be exhausting); the icons designed for lower resolution monitors that are now almost too small to distinguish could be forgiven if they had provided a SEARCH function (wth is going on with those categories); the sims point store could be ignored if they weren't constantly advertising promos; the worlds are beautiful but saves are silo'd; why isn't there a calendar?; and then there is the embarrassing same-ness of body builds, every ethnicity feels like a color variation of the same thing. From a S4 pov you can see why EA decided to scrap this and start over.

In the end, 5/5 - it's a tie for me although I'll probably lean towards S4 because I love to build and am spoiled by moving and copying rooms. If Sims 5 could merge the strengths of each we'd have a real winner. For now I'll appreciate what each can offer because it's just a game and not worth stressing over.

Regardless of how I may enjoy the game in the near future when I finally get it to work, EA is a piece of shit for making the Sims a so expensive title after a shitload of years. The only reason I bought it is that I don't bother with downloading pirated copies anymore and the game was on 'sale'. 

Anyway apart from the absurd pricing (not even AAA titles released around 2009 still cost this much) the DLC grab is the worst I've ever seen (compared to it Payday 2 and Rome Total War II shine for their decency) and the game is so incomplete without any of them that... I won't even finish the phrase. What I suggested to do before I edited my review could have earned me a ban.

Finally the only reason I'm wasting my time writing this, really, is that as I mentioned above the game doesn't work properly. Compatibility problems with W7 and 8 are massive and the troubleshooting required is at times just too much. I've been able to play some 4 hours and after relaunching the game everything turned wrong. First the costant crashing every 10 minutes, then every 5 and finally the freezing (every 2 or so). I tried to update again my gpu drivers only to find out the game does not recognise it and pick the built in intel card (playing on a laptop). Not saying the game will never work, but like Bethesda did with FO3 a label stating there are issues with newer systems and graphic cards should be added to the store page.

After so many years few will still buy this game but for the ones considering that option, just stay way.

This game saved my life.

I am 41.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you
very fun, looking into getting some expansion packs

Amazing! I've played Sims 2, 3 and 4, and Sims 3 has definitely been the best of the lot in my view. One of the best things is the way the lots are semi-open to the wide world: you can just walk out of one and into another, get in a car, drive around town, go to hangouts, etc. I love the busy, full towns with loads of places to work and have fun as well as all the residential lots full of sims, that you can visit and get to know. It's quite easy to design the worlds: much easier than in Sims 4.
My favourite expansions and game packs have been University Life (so good!) Island Paradise and Ambitions (being a firefighter is great!) I also love the world adventure one. The university and world adventures add benefits to your sims and they don't get any older and neither to the folks back home, plus they're just such fun experiences.
I like Seasons: I think it has a lot of perks, but it rains way too much and is cold too often too. It's a weird combination with island paradise! I ended up switching it off.
There have been some awesome worlds and other additions over the years too. like the Italian place with the pizza ovens, and the boardwalk with the roller coasters.
I never use cheats (I did a bit back in Sims 2 days) and Sims 3 is so playable without them.
I don't really like the obsession with the signs of the zodiac, and alien abduction is just annoying and boring. Also ghosts get a bit boring, especially with people dying quite a lot as your sims lives and towns progress. Leave out the star signs and the aliens and rein in the ghosts and it's near a perfect 10. As it is, I give it 8/10.

This was honestly THE game of my childhood and something I found joy in during a lot of hard times. I've been playing Sims 4 more than 3 lately, but I'm not really sure why. I love the gameplay mechanics, I love how personizable it is, with mods and custom content, but I also deeply enjoy the base and expansions as they are. I've got 200+ hours logged on steam, but the laptop from my teen years had a disk copy and at least 300 hours before the computer just kicked the bucket. I'm pretty sure their catchphrase or whatever is 'Play with life' and this game 100% delivers on that. It's fun and there's an almost endless amount of things to do. 
And a pro tip! I bought all my DLC during steam sales where it was all $5 each, and I really can't think of a better deal than that. hold out for those sales! If you enjoy Sims, it's worth it to drop $40 on 8 expansion/stuff/whatever packs. 

All in all, no matter what happens Sims 3 will remain one of my all time favorite video games for life.

I love it

Let's get one thing clear,  I'm a pretty boring sims player.  What I like doing most in the game is just taking care of a simple family and seeing how far I can get a family tree to go. I've always loved doing this in The Sims and it is a very cool way to show playtime and progress. Firstly, I'd probably say that the Sims 3 in terms of content is the best in the series even years later I'm still finding stuff I didn't even know I was in the game.  Sims 3’s  open world structure is also very nice and it's something that I miss when I play The Sims 4.  The ui is laid out very nicely. It's very easy to figure out what your sim needs.  You can get lost in this game for hours Taking care of an imaginary family or doing whatever your heart desires. However I do have some gripes about the Sims 3 even though the positives well outweigh the negatives.  Even though this is the better game in some respects, The Sims 4 streamlines things Much better than the Sims 3. For example, one of the most useless periods for a sim  is when they are newborns. The Sims 4 remedies this by letting you age up a newborn straight to a toddler. The Sims 3 doesn't have this feature. again it's minor but it's very much appreciated.  Also this game is optimized horribly on  newer machines. I physically had to go into the files of the game to fix certain settings and change certain  variables so that the game runs better. I would also highly recommend against the island paradise DLC, as it runs horribly on any machine I tested it on.  Overall, even though I like The Sims  4 more,  The Sims 3 is an extremely close second and I highly recommend it on sale or not. also the expansion packs in this game have a lot more in them than the Sims 4 in my opinion so if you can get any of the expansion packs on sale I'd definitely pick up a few. 97/100

As someone who has been playing The Sims as a whole for over 12 years, The Sims 3 will always be the game that I go back to - it was the first game in the series that I played, and it's the one that I have the most memories of.

I've had the Origin version of the game since 2013 because before that I was playing on console, and from 2015 onwards the game has been virtually impossible to run since the release of patch 1.69; I've had performance issues, compatibility issues and it has generally just been a hassle to play, so my playtime has dropped drastically.

I was looking at the Steam sale and noticed that the Sims 3 collection was on sale and so was the basegame, so I spent my remaining Christmas money on it and I can't explain how much easier it has been to play. The game is so much more stable even though I'm now running more DLC than I was before on Origin, and I have CC and Mods added in too. The FPS is stable, I can have my graphics up high again, and I haven't enjoyed the game this much since patch 1.69 came out, honestly.

Thank god Steam is on 1.67, I don't know what I'd do otherwise.

I absolutely love this game and I highly favor it over Sims 4. While its sequel has certainly improved in quality in recent years, I don't think that it'll ever hit the same notes that this game did. 

The open world, the Create A Style tool, the townie's story progression, all are leaps and bounds over both Sims 2 and 4 in what it adds to the gameplay experience. This game brought so much to the table that it to this day holds up as the standard Life Simulation game. 

The game, however, isn't without its faults. My biggest qualm with this game is the numerous technical issues that come with running a 12 year old game running on modern hardware. Simply put, it hasn't aged well. While there are a plethora of community-made fixes / game patches that claim to solve these issues, such as the nRaas mods and LazyDuchess' recently released Smooth Patch, not even these two combined along are enough to make Sims 3 run as smoothly as desired. Regardless, you shouldn't have to install a whole bunch of fan made patches just to PLAY the damn thing. Maxis was being somewhat truthful when they said that the game's open world and create a style tools were taken away in Sims 4 to allow for better performance, but I still can't help but feel like a lot of the problems faced while playing come as a result of a lack of future-proofing on their part.

If you're willing to look past the unoptimization and bugs, though, you'll find what is truly a worthwhile gaming experience that few other life sim games have ever or will ever achieve, and that is what earns this game a positive review.

Everything about the Sims is awesome!! I really love that my characters can age up and I can decide how fast or slow I want them to get older. I love how many different lots there are, and how I can customize each house I build but that there are also pre-built rooms you can add to your house. I think the most time I spend in the game is designing homes for my Sims. 

The expansions have some great content but definitely aren't worth the full price. I had 3 expansions/stuff packs already and just got the rest of them (16) in a bundle for only $56 during the winter sale!! I think I may get a little overwhelmed exploring 16 expansions all at once, but I'm excited to try new careers and get all the new items! The late night expansion is really neat, it adds a city where your sim can live in an apartment building and go to night clubs, or become a vampire if you want. I've been making a new family for each expansion I buy, in order to fully experience each one. The world traveler one is really cool because it allows you to travel to 3 different countries and explore tombs, meet locals, and add new skills (such as martial arts in China). 

The only real negative for me is some of the customization when making your Sim. Most of the hairstyles are terrible, and there aren't always great options for clothing and other features. You do get some new clothing options from each expansion, so that helps a lot. In a previous version of the sims (maybe the Sims 2, I can't remember), you could have your sim go shopping in town and buy new outfits. I wish that were an option in this version, it would be nice to have options in my sims' wardrobe. One thing I like about it though is that you can customize a different outfit for different activities: everyday, swimwear, outerwear, sleepwear, and formal wear. So that's nice, they automatically change clothes depending on what they're doing.
