Why Sims 3 over Sims 4:
-Open World design, no loading screens.
-More options and functions, a more complex game that can be difficult but rewarding for those who are willing to get familiar with the deep and intricate systems in it
-Evil characters are more fun to play with here (taking "evil" showers, take evil slumber)
-Job performance was more difficult but you had more control over it due to the conditions being more clear.
-The game gives you more reason to make friends, with your job and personal life benefiting from being social
-The game feels more alive, with characters that are not in your control being able to have kids, fall in love with other sims, and have jobs of their own. Sims 4 felt too constrained to your own household

Why Sims 4 over Sims 3:
-Better UI
-MUCH more simpler for newcomers to the series, smaller learning curve
-Better graphics
-WAAAAY better optimization. Sims 4 runs better than the Sims 3 on my PC,
-Recognizes GPUs after 2013 without the use of mods
-The mood mechanic is actually pretty cool
-Smaller neighbourhoods/towns means that it's easier for people who enjoy playing multiple families within the same save file

TL;DR: Play Sims 4 if you're new to the series to get a grasp of the game and it's mechanics. Play Sims 3 if you're like me and got bored of Sims 4 after easily mastering said mechanics and prefer more complex systems with higher difficulty

Sims 3 is arguably the best game in the franchise, with plenty of quirky features in the main game to keep you entertained for hours and lots of DLCs to enhance your Sims' adventures.

PROS
-Most expansive, customized building mode of the entire series
-Fun DLCs that can add value to your experience (Want to be a vampire? Own a unicorn? You can do all of these things and more with the right DLC)
-Plenty of quirky Sim interactions that keep the game fresh and enjoyable

CONS
-The game can absolutely lag, especially if you install multiple DLCs
-The choices for textured hair are really lacking in the Create a Sim feature
-Prices for DLCs are a bit high for a game as old as this one (I would wait for a sale)

In addition to the main Sims 3 game, I've played the following DLCs: Supernatural, Pets, Seasons, Generations, World Adventures, and Ambitions. For those whose game tends to lag a lot, I recommend Pets, Seasons, and Generations. You can still have lots of fun with those DLCs added to the base game. My favorite DLC, though, is absolutely Supernatural; it adds so much to the overall experience and gameplay that I can't praise it enough. I'm fairly ambivalent about Ambitions, which lets you choose a career and actually make decisions/move while working. Some of the options for careers are entertaining, like ghost-hunting, but I mostly found this DLC to be glitchy (could just be issues on my end, though).

All in all, Sims 3 is a great game and one of the stronger editions of the Sims franchise.

The game itself is good, but its unoptimized state makes the gameplay unenjoyable:
- During its entire lifetime, outside of MacOS, the game has never been updated to 64-bit. This makes it lag, stutter, and crash often on newer computers and require a lot of additional tweaking from the player's end to resolve said issues. However, in my case, using performance-improving mods (from NRass) breaks the game even further without showing any sign of performance improvement.
- The loading and saving times get ridiculously longer for every savegame over time and the performance standard has become so low that many players think 15 minutes to load a save is fast and 30 minutes (even without any custom content) is acceptable.
- Launcher still runs in the background after starting the game, using more hardware resources than needed.
- Despite the discontinuation of update long ago, the base game and all of its DLC's are still incredibly expensive.

Not worth buying at all.

I never even bothered reviewing this? 
Well fine.  Yes, this is a good game, even if the full experience costs the GDP of a small country. 

Most importantly, it has been on Steam since before Origin was around, so it doesn't require any sort of EA account nor Origin to play (though it is still recommended that you bypass the launcher). 

It is an absolutely wonderful torture simulator. The perfect game for making innocent people lead horrible lives, leading eventually to horrible and amusing deaths. 
There are also tons of adult mods for it, so it can double as a porn-game... and plenty of torture / murder mods too.  Well, and just quality-of-life mods, but those are an afterthought. 


Downsides include insane loading times and instability (both of which get worse as the game progresses and more things have to be committed to memory),  the cost, the way the characters sound overwhelmingly American even when speaking complete nonsense, and the inability to kill small children. 
I'm sure at least some of those can be fixed with mods. Maybe I should look to see if there is an accent-changer mod... but I doubt it.   There probably is one for putting babies in blenders though, so I should be able to recreate Mai-Chan's Daily Life.

As much as I love this game for nostalgic reasons, I can't recommend getting it on Steam if you get it at all.

EA seems committed to screwing over Steam players, like they didn't put it for sale on Steam in the first place. They don't offer patches for the Steam version anymore, which means that unless you jerry-rig your installation to use an aftermarket patch, you can't use any content you PAID FOR on the Sims 3 Exchange.

Long time fan of the series right from the original game "The Sims" & stuck with Sims 2 for the longest time, recently moved on to 3 and so far love it. If you liked the previous sims games you will love this one too. 

The only downside is it is buggy and can be laggy, nothing game breaking at least that I've come across so far, but until I added game-fixing mods and  added more memory it had crashed to the desktop a few times but only intermittently which was an annoyance but normally  not an issue as long as I remembered to save after any major progress & often I could play for hours before it happened.

For  me I enjoy the game enough its worth putting up with the flaws and (until I added more memory) odd rude desktop interruption. If you do get it I'd recommend installing the nraas mods Overwatch, ErrorTrap & traveler (although the latter perhaps only if you're going to move your sims to a new neighbourhood, send them on holiday, to uni etc) as they help catch and repair errors & replace the at times broken travel system as the issues occur. With Errortrap make sure you get the steam version not origin though as unlike all the other nraas mods it matters and the origin version is not compatible with the Steam version.  Flawed due to the bugs but I think its worth it and if you enjoyed sims 2  you'll probably like this as well.

The game itself is great, no doubt. Yes, it's pretty laggy, but honestly if you have a look at all of the content that you get, you can easily forget about the lags. 
Ok, enough sugar-coating: Let's be honest. The price (especially the add-ons!) is absolutely ridiculous considering the fact that the game is 10 years old. EA loves to charge insane amounts of money for all kinds of games, even the ones like Sims 3. I love the game but that doesn't change the fact that it is holding on for dear life, because of its oldness. 
Still, the game is awesome and while I do recommend it, you should always keep in mind the amount of money you might spend on it (especially the dlc's that come with it!).

What I like:
+Open world. You can explore the world at any time anywhere which is really cool and this is exactly what Sims 4 is lacking the most. 
+Deep costumization like never before
+The DLCs are million times better than Sims 4 could only ever dreams of

What I dislike:

-Very unoptomized and low FPS. Unfortunately the only issue that frustrates me is the not-so-optimization. The game would lag constantly when you explore the world and this issue exists for newer graphics cards.
-Lack of world maps and variety with most DLCs 
-Maps are locked behind online DRM. It would've been fine if they added map pack or stuff pack from sims store web on steam I'll happily pay 50 dollars just for that.
-Atrocious load times and especially the god awful long ass unskippable intro videos
-Doesn't properly save and doesn't use Steam's cloud save service
-Does not play well on laptop, it gets hot very quickly

9/10

Life, as they say, is a journey. Your journey and with Sims 3 you can shoot for the stars or just see your sim mess up at every Turn. You can live out your life digitally that you really wanted. There is plenty to explore and do in the Sims 3. I really liked playing the first sims...so thought the Sims 3 would be a sound investment. 

The Sims 3 has many additions  to the game
UNIVERSITY - Go to University excel and get good grades...or just go to party's and get drunk
SUPERNATURAL - Supernatural is focused on bringing new life states to the game, and establishes an appropriate setting for these creatures to live in one town with Moonlight Falls. This guide will cover the largest  additions for owners of this Expansion Pack.
AMBITIONS - Ambitions is the best expansion pack for Simmers who like to make money. This is a great add on as it brings five new professions, one changed one, and several other ways to make money. The highlights of the  the professions. Sims can be a ghost hunter, firefighter, stylist, architect, or private investigator. These pay a weekly stipend and give you money per job.
PETS - If you don't like pets, you won't like this Expansion. Its primary contributions are Cats, Dogs, and Horses. Cats and Dogs 
And many many add on and downloadable content

 RATING 7/10

I am a long time Sims player. Since Sims 1. Sims 3 is defiantly my favorite version. I love the wide world to explore and the cars. And I really enjoy World Adventures. I was always hoping they would add other vacation destinations. Anyway  I'm glad its on Steam now as I always seem to have trouble with Oracal (SP). Although I have to now get all the expansions again. That will take me some time. But I got s few my favorite expansions first: Late Night, Ambitions, Showtime, and World Adventures.

[b]Introduction: [/b] Before you comment on my hours. I played this game when it was first released during my high school years long before Steam. While every one of my friends played Battlefield or Call of Duty, I played this almost every chance I got. But this review is going to be about comparing Sims 3 with Sims 4. Both good and bad points of each game, something I wanted to do for so long.

[b]TLDR part at the bottom![/b]

[h1] Review Score:  8/10[/h1] 

[u] Sims 3: [/u]
[list]
    [*] (+) Tons of meaningful and fun content to explore. With open-world, there are tons of things for your sims to do. You could spend hours upon hours playing on one sim or a whole family. I know I spent my entire high school life here. Be warned, you can get incredibly addicted for days, weeks, months, or even years like I did.

    [*] (+) Music and sound design is fantastic. Tons of parody of real life songs but in Simlish(Sim's gibberish language) and there is a ton of heart into each sim's interaction with the world. I still have the entire soundtrack on my phone to listen to whenever I feel like it. I even heard sims 3 music in an unrelated documentary and advertisement. It's that good!

    [*] (=) The expansion content is fantastic with tons of content with meaningful changes to the world and how you play with it. Seasons and Pets is my all-time favorites, but I still enjoyed World Adventures and Generations. All of the expansions I highly recommend to get if you looking for more content. But... the stuff packs are really just bland... They are literally "free update" level in quality & quantity. One of their DLCs is outright unplayable garbage, take a wild guess which one that is(check the reviews)... They never bothered to fix it, have to find a janky workaround for it. OH! It's also ridiculously OVERPRICED! The game is 12 years old now, why the fuck is it still $20+? Get on sale only!

    [*] (-) This game runs like a beat up engine of an old used car. The optimization was abysmal back then and even now. It is very difficult to play this game without technical mods to improve the stability and the overall performance. Load times can be very long and almost astronomically long if you have many mods installed. I remember I had a decent amount of mods installed to improve the game and it took like 20 - 30 minutes of loading(once).

    [*] (-) The art design did not age very well. Even when this game came out in 2009 the models, textures, and effects were ugly. It definitely did it no favors in the current time, even with graphic mods. Ridiculed then and now... There is limit to how much you can polish something this hideous. 

[/list]

[u] Sims 4: [/u]
[list]
    [*] (+) The better QoL improvements to build mode, create-a-sim mode, and live mode makes doing creative content a lot easier to handle especially for beginners. I made tons of unique houses and sims to the point where I got curated by the Maxis developers at one point. It's hard to explain every positive change, but I won't lie... I had a hard time going back to Sims 3 build mode. Although, their CAS mode could use a slider system and Create-a-Style feature. You can live without them, but it does hamper on potential creativity. The ability to have Sims multi-task multiple duties makes the game play far less rigid and more natural than ever before.

    [*] (+) Very well optimized, you can pretty much on any computer system including crappy laptops. I know I played a bit when I was overseas and had nothing to play. The constant short loading times can be annoying, but you can largely ignore them. You can actually play this game without any mods installed. I recommend a few gameplay-enhancing ones to give the game more depth that it lacks.

    [*] (=) The introduction to the Gallery makes it easier for people to find custom houses, sims, or rooms to download for them to use in their own world. It was always fun to see what actual creative people can make... minus all of those [Teen Pregnancy or Jersey Shore or Monster-mash sims that has plagued the platform for years... shudders...]. Because it lets ANYONE upload their creation, there is little to no quality control. All the great content can be buried under tons of awful ones. But when you find that one great one, it makes you really appreciate the community.

    [*] (-) Lack of free-roam of any kind past neighborhoods. This is major downside and what made TONS of players leave the series all-together. Sure the loading times are faster, but there are tons of them in-between everything you do outside your house. It completely disconnects you from your sims and the world... It's the part I absolutely hated. The neighborhood version they replaced with is okay in certain areas like City Life, but TERRIBLY lacking in other worlds. A complete waste of potential here.

    [*] (-) FAR weaker DLCs than their Sims 3 counterparts. Sims 4 Cats & Dogs is a joke compare to Pets, Sims 4 Seasons is okay... but less impact with the lack of free-roam, several expansions are split into stuff packs & game packs to milk the living crap out their fanbase's wallets. Then they decide to release "Kits" which are even more of an insult to injury. Remember when they made a DLC for a DLC? Yeah it's that bad... This game is notorious for having terrible DLC practice and it's only gotten worse. Majority of them are overpriced trash when compared to their predecessors(Sims 1 - 3).

[/list]

[h1]TLDR: [/h1]

Sims 3 is a giant diamond in the rough. It has tons of value, but incredibly rough around the edges. You have to do your own kind of polishing here.

Sims 4 is a tiny diamond but polished to a certain degree. Has much less meaningful content than its predecessors(Sims 1 - 3), but at least I can actually play it without much problems.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]

I can spend hours here listing all the pros and cons of each game. Both games have their own strengths and design philosophy, but when you take off the nostalgia goggles... Sims 3 is not as "perfect" some would make it out to be. The final verdict is that Sims 3 simply just a "better" thought out game made by a bunch of developers who loved the game and wanted to push the boundaries of the Life Simulator genre. Sims 3 is a great sequel to the Sims franchise. Sims 4 is a decent sequel to Sims 2, but a bad sequel to Sims 3.

In conclusion? It's okay to enjoy both titles, but I understand why people love this game more than the latest iteration. This was a time when EA didn't completely suck, when they weren't the one of the worst game companies to ever exist. You know games like Dragon Age Origins, Sims 3, FIFA 10, Battlefield Bad Company, Dead Space, and etc. Now look at where all of these franchises become...

The Sims has always been a fun game for me as it brings back vivid memories from early 2000's to now 2021 and I am sure beyond.

~I'll never forget not saving after promotions or a few hours and having a satellite fall from the sky and destroy my young & just starting out on her own sim.
~I was on the phone with a friend trying to finish up French homework (because no one could afford 10 cents a text back in the early 2000's) and their sim started a fire and had the alarm going off, meanwhile my sim started and fire and their alarm starts going off. They tragically did not make it, but the french homework got completed. C'est la vie n'est pas?
~ Move objects on cheat and moving a shower while a sim was in it scared me the first time - are they NEKKED?! - well yes but no but yes. I sometimes now put "never nude" as a personality trait as a cheeky reminder of my innocent shock.
~ The most memorable and embarrassing Sims related goof was when I had a birthday (in real life) and decided to try my sims favorite food (key lime pie). I never had key lime pie... and my first taste was tragically awful. My friends asked why I had never tried it before making it my birthday "cake/pie" and my response was "well my sim loves it". I still get sass for that.

These games helped define me growing up - they were an easy ice breaker when I didn't know what to talk about and they helped relieve stress when I would make my least favorite person in the game and make their lives miserable... I always turned into a sap and got them an okay lifestyle even if the real life version of them was a complete doo-doo head.

Hope you give it a try who knows maybe your sim will get a unsolicited picture in the mail to enjoy.

Only says 5 hours on my account as I used to play this game on Origin and have hundreds of hours over nearly 10 years now.

Great customisation thanks to lots of traits that make Sims feel unique, and that are implemented in-depth to the point where there's more in the Sims 3 base game than all packs in the Sims 4. All Sims feel unique and I get attached to most, once I nearly cried because my Sim's girlfriend died and he mourned her for days. I also love the option to change the lifespans, as for some stories I want them to last for a long time while others work better with the traditional lifespan. Also Create-A-Style is amazing, even though I don't use it in-depth, I like colour-coding which bed belongs to which Sim, especially in large households. This means that they can all have matching beds which I much prefer over having to get different beds to suit the swatches I need in sometimes 2 & especially 4. 

I also love the open-world as it allows an ease of exploration & story-telling without the loading screens of any other Sims game. Also like the art style. The environment is the best out of all Sims games (fight me). There is also some lore in the world which you can explore, which I enjoy but personally think they went more in-depth and did a better job with Sims 2.

The only drawbacks are that the design of the hair & clothes are bad which is what makes people think that the art style is bad, and that you can't have the option to play rotationally without mods, which I would prefer for some stories. But I forget about these easily as I cater my stories to the vanilla single-household play style of the Sims 3 (for now), and you forget about the looks quickly by being immersed by the game play.
 
Some people also have performance issues which they can't get over, I used to have a potato and in my personal opinion the game barely lagged with the lowest settings with most of the expansions enabled. Now though with a better laptop my gave runs smoothly.

Overall: 9/10. A must-have for Simmers, especially those who can't play 2. Can stand on its own but the rating gets amplified by the expansions, which although are expensive for how old they are they still have 1000x better quality than the current expansions we get today.

I know there's a Sims 4, but Sims 3 is my favorite because I don't have to get a second mortgage and sell my soul to afford the expansion packs for this one(although there aren't that many mods for Sims 3 which is very sad).  Like any Sims game, you'll pick this game up, put 100 hours into it, uninstall it, and in a few months you'll come crawling back to either find out what your disastrous household is up to or you'll start a new family that will no doubt ruin the lives of their friends and family and disappoint everyone around them.  

Your sims will woohoo with grandmas, cheat spouses out of their money and kick them out of their own houses, lock other sims in basements and leave them to starve and pee themselves to death, flirt with the grim reaper, steal people's curtains, get fired from jobs, find creepy gnomes in the garden, randomly start rooting through a dumpster instead of sitting and eating with their date, and so much more.  Chaos, disaster, death, and unfulfilled dreams are just $20 away(or a mere $400 if you buy all the 10+ year old expansions at full price).

Its the sims...again. Over the years I've tried the different sims games, the graphics gets better, the interaction gets more varied but it really just boils down to a simple thing. It's your personal soap opera where you're the director.
The core components are basically the same with each sims version. Aging and other effects create a slightly different dynamic. Would I buy Sims 4? Only if it came in a bundle sale on steam and had smaller game save files. Do I have fun with it? Sure, but then I can have fun with a lot of simpler games. It's cheap to get if you grab the bundle on holidays and hours of play if you like Storytelling. Yes, its basically playing with a digital dollhouse or "action figures." Then again, most games are in the most basic sense the same concept of make believe and playing hero or bad guy.

Sims 3 does have a number of bugs that have never been addressed even now. Sims 4 is reportedly less game breaking. NRAAS has appeared to solve a lot of issues with Sims 3 as a community developed fix. As I understand it, it's a script that cleans up things in the game each day. re-routing stuck characters, removing extras, turning off televisions, etc. 
It's not bad though it is a broken game if you play it long enough without the community fixes. With the fixes it trudges along and on sale days it's cheaper than sims 4.

A good choice for a Sims game, assuming you can get it to run. The trait based gameplay greatly expanded on the older games in the franchise, and is a change I greatly appreciate. Instead of personality points from older games, now if you want your sim to be a say, kleptomaniac, you can do that. Everyone now feels more connected to each other thanks to the open neighbourhood. The existence of create a style is a nice addition I’ll miss from The Sims 4, as I often used it to get matching clothes or furniture.

Unfortunately, the game often suffers from stutters and lag because the game is always trying to keep track of what every sim in the neighbourhood is doing at once. Public lots often take a long time to populate thanks to everyone’s scattered schedules, even when the club your sim is at is supposedly a hotspot. Another issue is the lack of proper art direction which is a big deal in a series based around decorating, building, and dressing your sims. The textures used for clothes can be waxy and the assets often seem like they don’t belong to the same game. This isn’t a personal problem for me, but should be taken into account by more avid builders or decorators.

Although The Sims 3 has its problems, I enjoyed playing it overall, even without the purchase of any DLCs. If you’re a more family focused player, I recommend this to try out before The Sims 4.

If you're not too worried about graphics, the Sims 3 might as well be called "Sims 4 For Those On A Budget". Can I make Sims? Yes. Can I build houses? Yes. I have to admit I'm not a Sims fanatic, this is just something I play when I want to relax, so I don't have the authority to wax poetic about the gripping gameplay or whatever, but if you're like me and want to play the Sims like a filthy casual but don't want to pay £40 for Sims 4 or risk bricking your computer by doing something illegal Sims 3 is for you. 

That said it's a goddamn crime this game is 12 years old and EA STILL wants to charge like £20 EACH for the DLCs, like COME. ON! Also maybe I just haven't found it yet but I wish this game had a windowed mode, I like to keep track of time when I play vidya otherwise left unattended I will play for hours on end or until my spine decides enough is enough.

If you look past the dated clothing/building(s)/and overall lifestyle, its an amazing game with tons to do, which is a VERY stark difference from the sims 4. 

A nice bonus is that its one of very few EA games that you can play with or without DLC fairly comfortably, however selling your soul to EA does give you some nice worlds and new options for your sims etc etc.
